characters.name: Survival
characters.importance_exp: The theme highlights the harsh realities of survival in the face of danger.
characters.quote: Scylla pounced down suddenly upon us and snatched up my six best men

scenes.title: Arrival at Thrinacian Island
scenes.summary: Ulysses warns his men about the sun-god's cattle.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Thrinacian Island.
scenes.text:
Charybdis, we reached the noble island of the sun-god, where were the
goodly cattle and sheep belonging t'the sun Hyperion. While still at
sea in my ship I could bear the cattle lowing as they came home t'the
yards, and the sheep bleating. Then I remembered what the blind Theban
prophet Teiresias had told me, and how carefully Aeaean Circe had
warned me t'shun the island of the blessed sun-god. S'being much
troubled I said t'the men, 'My men, I know you are hard pressed, but
listen while I tell you the prophecy that Teiresias made me, and how
carefully Aeaean Circe warned me t'shun the island of the blessed
sun-god, for it was here, she said, that our worst danger would lie.
Head the ship, therefore, away from the island.'

characters.name: Divine Warning
characters.importance_exp: This theme is crucial as it drives the characters' actions.
characters.quote: I remembered what the blind Theban prophet Teiresias had told me, and how carefully Aeaean Circe had warned me t'shun the island of the blessed sun-god.

characters.name: Desperation For Help
characters.importance_exp: The men's desperation influences their decision-making.
characters.quote: My men, I know you are hard pressed, but listen while I tell you the prophecy that Teiresias made me.

characters.name: Monstrous Threats
characters.importance_exp: The theme of danger is central to the scene's tension.
characters.quote: for it was here, she said, that our worst danger would lie.

scenes.title: Eurylochus' Rebellion
scenes.summary: Eurylochus convinces the men to eat the sun-god's cattle.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the island.
scenes.text:
"The men were in despair at this, and Eurylochus at once gave me an
insolent answer. 'Ulysses,' said he, 'you are cruel; you are very
strong yourself and never get worn out; you seem t'be made of iron,
and now, though your men are exhausted with toil and want of sleep, you
will not let them land and cook themselves a good supper upon this
island, but bid them put out t'sea and g'faring fruitlessly on
through the watches of the flying night. It is by night that the winds
blow hardest and d's'much damage; how can we escape should one of
those sudden squalls spring up from South West or West, which s'often
wreck a vessel when our lords the gods are unpropitious? Now,
therefore, let us obey the behests of night and prepare our supper here
hard by the ship; to-morrow morning we will g'on board again and put
out t'sea.'
"Thus spoke Eurylochus, and the men approved his words. I saw that
heaven meant us a mischief and said, 'You force me t'yield, for you
are many against one, but at any rate each one of you must take his
solemn oath that if he meet with a herd of cattle or a large flock of
sheep, he will not be s'mad as t'kill a single head of either, but
will be satisfied with the food that Circe has given us.'
"They all swore as I bade them, and when they had completed their oath
we made the ship fast in a harbour that was near a stream of fresh
water, and the men went ashore and cooked their suppers. As soon as
they had had enough t'eat and drink, they began talking about their
poor comrades whom Scylla had snatched up and eaten; this set them
weeping and they went on crying till they fell off int'a sound sleep.
"In the third watch of the night when the stars had shifted their
places, Jove raised a great gale of wind that flew a hurricane s'that
land and sea were covered with thick clouds, and night sprang forth out
of the heavens. When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn,
appeared, we brought the ship t'land and drew her int'a cave wherein
the sea-nymphs hold their courts and dances, and I called the men
together in council.
"'My friends,' said I, 'we have meat and drink in the ship, let us
mind, therefore, and not touch the cattle, or we shall suffer for it;
for these cattle and sheep belong t'the mighty sun, wh'sees and gives
ear t'everything.' And again they promised that they would obey.
"For a whole month the wind blew steadily from the South, and there was
n'other wind, but only South and East.105 As long as corn and wine
held out the men did not touch the cattle when they were hungry; when,
however, they had eaten all there was in the ship, they were forced to
g'further afield, with hook and line, catching birds, and taking
whatever they could lay their hands on; for they were starving. One
day, therefore, I went up inland that I might pray heaven t'show me
some means of getting away. When I had gone far enough t'be clear of
all my men, and had found a place that was well sheltered from the
wind, I washed my hands and prayed t'all the gods in Olympus till by
and by they sent me off int'a sweet sleep.
"Meanwhile Eurylochus had been giving evil counsel t'the men, 'Listen
t'me,' said he, 'my poor comrades. All deaths are bad enough but there
is none s'bad as famine. Why should not we drive in the best of these
cows and offer them in sacrifice t'the immortal gods? If we ever get
back t'Ithaca, we can build a fine temple t'the sun-god and enrich it
with every kind of ornament; if, however, he is determined t'sink our
ship out of revenge for these horned cattle, and the other gods are of
the same mind, I for one would rather drink salt water once for all and

characters.name: Loss Of Hope
characters.importance_exp: The men's despair drives their actions in this scene.
characters.quote: The men were in despair at this, and Eurylochus at once gave me an insolent answer.

characters.name: Leadership And Obedience
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' leadership is challenged by the crew's discontent.
characters.quote: You force me t'yield, for you are many against one.

characters.name: Divine Retribution
characters.importance_exp: The fear of divine punishment influences the crew's decisions.
characters.quote: for these cattle and sheep belong t'the mighty sun, wh'sees and gives ear t'everything.

characters.name: Manipulation
characters.importance_exp: Eurylochus' bad advice leads to a critical turning point.
characters.quote: Eurylochus had been giving evil counsel t'the men.

scenes.title: Divine Retribution
scenes.summary: The sun-god punishes Ulysses' men for killing the cattle.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the sea after leaving the island.
scenes.text:
have done with it, than be starved t'death by inches in such a desert
island as this is.'
"Thus spoke Eurylochus, and the men approved his words. Now the cattle,
s'fair and goodly, were feeding not far from the ship; the men,
therefore, drove in the best of them, and they all stood round them
saying their prayers, and using young oak-shoots instead of
barley-meal, for there was n'barley left. When they had done praying
they killed the cows and dressed their carcasses; they cut out the
thigh bones, wrapped them round in tw'layers of fat, and set some
pieces of raw meat on top of them. They had n'wine with which t'make
drink-offerings over the sacrifice while it was cooking, s'they kept
pouring on a little water from time t'time while the inward meats were
being grilled; then, when the thigh bones were burned and they had
tasted the inward meats, they cut the rest up small and put the pieces
upon the spits.
"By this time my deep sleep had left me, and I turned back t'the ship
and t'the sea shore. As I drew near I began t'smell hot roast meat,
s'I groaned out a prayer t'the immortal gods. 'Father Jove,' I
exclaimed, 'and all you other gods wh'live in everlasting bliss, you
have done me a cruel mischief by the sleep int'which you have sent me;
see what fine work these men of mine have been making in my absence.'
"Meanwhile Lampetie went straight off t'the sun and told him we had
been killing his cows, whereon he flew int'a great rage, and said to
the immortals, 'Father Jove, and all you other gods wh'live in
everlasting bliss, I must have vengeance on the crew of Ulysses' ship:
they have had the insolence t'kill my cows, which were the one thing I
loved t'look upon, whether I was going up heaven or down again. If
they d'not square accounts with me about my cows, I will g'down to
Hades and shine there among the dead.'
"'Sun,' said Jove, 'g'on shining upon us gods and upon mankind over
the fruitful earth. I will shiver their ship int'little pieces with a
bolt of white lightning as soon as they get out t'sea.'
"I was told all this by Calypso, wh'said she had heard it from the
mouth of Mercury.
"As soon as I got down t'my ship and t'the sea shore I rebuked each
one of the men separately, but we could see n'way out of it, for the
cows were dead already. And indeed the gods began at once t'show signs
and wonders among us, for the hides of the cattle crawled about, and
the joints upon the spits began t'low like cows, and the meat, whether
cooked or raw, kept on making a noise just as cows do.
"For six days my men kept driving in the best cows and feasting upon
them, but when Jove the son of Saturn had added a seventh day, the fury
of the gale abated; we therefore went on board, raised our masts,
spread sail, and put out t'sea. As soon as we were well away from the
island, and could see nothing but sky and sea, the son of Saturn raised
a black cloud over our ship, and the sea grew dark beneath it. We did
not get on much further, for in another moment we were caught by a
terrific squall from the West that snapped the forestays of the mast so
that it fell aft, while all the ship's gear tumbled about at the bottom
of the vessel. The mast fell upon the head of the helmsman in the
ship's stern, s'that the bones of his head were crushed t'pieces, and
he fell overboard as though he were diving, with n'more life left in
him.
"Then Jove let fly with his thunderbolts, and the ship went round and
round, and was filled with fire and brimstone as the lightning struck
it. The men all fell int'the sea; they were carried about in the water
round the ship, looking like s'many sea-gulls, but the god presently
deprived them of all chance of getting home again.

characters.name: Divine Retribution
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central as it drives the plot forward with consequences for the crew's actions.
characters.quote: 'If they d'not square accounts with me about my cows, I will g'down to Hades and shine there among the dead.'

characters.name: Disobedience
characters.importance_exp: The crew's actions directly lead to their downfall, highlighting the consequences of disobedience.
characters.quote: I rebuked each one of the men separately, but we could see n'way out of it, for the cows were dead already.

characters.name: Sacrifice And Offerings
characters.importance_exp: The act of sacrificing the cows signifies a turning point and the desperation of the crew.
characters.quote: they killed the cows and dressed their carcasses; they cut out the thigh bones, wrapped them round in tw'layers of fat, and set some pieces of raw meat on top of them.

scenes.title: Ulysses' Survival
scenes.summary: Ulysses survives the storm and is carried to the Ogygian island.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the sea and then to Ogygian island.
scenes.text:
"I stuck t'the ship till the sea knocked her sides from her keel
(which drifted about by itself) and struck the mast out of her in the
direction of the keel; but there was a backstay of stout ox-thong still
hanging about it, and with this I lashed the mast and keel together,
and getting astride of them was carried wherever the winds chose to
take me.
"[The gale from the West had now spent its force, and the wind got into
the South again, which frightened me lest I should be taken back t'the
terrible whirlpool of Charybdis. This indeed was what actually
happened, for I was borne along by the waves all night, and by sunrise
had reached the rock of Scylla, and the whirlpool. She was then sucking
down the salt sea water,106 but I was carried aloft toward the fig
tree, which I caught hold of and clung on t'like a bat. I could not
plant my feet anywhere s'as t'stand securely, for the roots were a
long way off and the boughs that overshadowed the whole pool were too
high, to'vast, and to'far apart for me t'reach them; s'I hung
patiently on, waiting till the pool should discharge my mast and raft
again—and a very long while it seemed. A jury-man is not more glad to
get home t'supper, after having been long detained in court by
troublesome cases, than I was t'see my raft beginning t'work its way
out of the whirlpool again. At last I let g'with my hands and feet,
and fell heavily int'the sea, hard by my raft on t'which I then got,
and began t'row with my hands. As for Scylla, the father of gods and
men would not let her get further sight of me—otherwise I should have
certainly been lost.107
"Hence I was carried along for nine days till on the tenth night the
gods stranded me on the Ogygian island, where dwells the great and
powerful goddess Calypso. She took me in and was kind t'me, but I need
say n'more about this, for I told you and your noble wife all about it
yesterday, and I hate saying the same thing over and over again."

characters.name: Survival
characters.importance_exp: Survival is the central focus of the scene as the character struggles against the elements.
characters.quote: I lashed the mast and keel together, and getting astride of them was carried wherever the winds chose to take me.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The role of the gods is significant as they influence the character's fate.
characters.quote: the father of gods and men would not let her get further sight of me—otherwise I should have certainly been lost.

characters.name: Isolation And Perseverance
characters.importance_exp: The character experiences profound isolation while clinging to the fig tree.
characters.quote: I could not plant my feet anywhere s'as t'stand securely, for the roots were a long way off...

scenes.title: Ulysses Departs Scheria
scenes.summary: Ulysses prepares to leave Scheria after receiving gifts.
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES LEAVES SCHERIA AND RETURNS T'ITHACA.
Thus did he speak, and they all held their peace throughout the covered
cloister, enthralled by the charm of his story, till presently Alcinous
began t'speak.
"Ulysses," said he, "now that you have reached my house I doubt not you
will get home without further misadventure n'matter how much you have
suffered in the past. T'you others, however, wh'come here night after
night t'drink my choicest wine and listen t'my bard, I would insist
as follows. Our guest has already packed up the clothes, wrought
gold,108 and other valuables which you have brought for his acceptance;
let us now, therefore, present him further, each one of us, with a
large tripod and a cauldron. We will recoup ourselves by the levy of a
general rate; for private individuals cannot be expected t'bear the
burden of such a handsome present."
Every one approved of this, and then they went home t'bed each in his
own abode. When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared they
hurried down t'the ship and brought their cauldrons with them.
Alcinous went on board and saw everything s'securely stowed under the
ship's benches that nothing could break adrift and injure the rowers.
Then they went t'the house of Alcinous t'get dinner, and he
sacrificed a bull for them in honour of Jove wh'is the lord of all.
They set the steaks t'grill and made an excellent dinner, after which
the inspired bard, Demodocus, wh'was a favourite with every one, sang
t'them; but Ulysses kept on turning his eyes towards the sun, as
though t'hasten his setting, for he was longing t'be on his way. As
one wh'has been all day ploughing a fallow field with a couple of oxen
keeps thinking about his supper and is glad when night comes that he
may g'and get it, for it is all his legs can d't'carry him, even so
did Ulysses rejoice when the sun went down, and he at once said t'the
Phaeacians, addressing himself more particularly t'King Alcinous:
"Sir, and all of you, farewell. Make your drink-offerings and send me
on my way rejoicing, for you have fulfilled my heart's desire by giving
me an escort, and making me presents, which heaven grant that I may
turn t'good account; may I find my admirable wife living in peace
among friends,109 and may you whom I leave behind me give satisfaction
t'your wives and children;110 may heaven vouchsafe you every good
grace, and may n'evil thing come among your people."
Thus did he speak. His hearers all of them approved his saying and
agreed that he should have his escort inasmuch as he had spoken
reasonably. Alcinous therefore said t'his servant, "Pontonous, mix
some wine and hand it round t'everybody, that we may offer a prayer to

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Ulysses' journey and desire.
characters.quote: Make your drink-offerings and send me on my way rejoicing, for you have fulfilled my heart's desire by giving me an escort, and making me presents, which heaven grant that I may turn t'good account; may I find my admirable wife living in peace among friends.

characters.name: Generosity
characters.importance_exp: The Phaeacians' hospitality is a key aspect of the scene.
characters.quote: let us now, therefore, present him further, each one of us, with a large tripod and a cauldron.

characters.name: Celebration
characters.importance_exp: The dinner and sacrifices highlight the theme of celebration.
characters.quote: he sacrificed a bull for them in honour of Jove wh'is the lord of all.

scenes.title: Arrival in Ithaca
scenes.summary: Ulysses arrives in Ithaca and is confused about his surroundings.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Ithaca.
scenes.text:
the ship drew near t'land.112 Now there is in Ithaca a haven of the
old merman Phorcys, which lies between tw'points that break the line
of the sea and shut the harbour in. These shelter it from the storms of
wind and sea that rage outside, s'that, when once within it, a ship
may lie without being even moored. At the head of this harbour there is
a large olive tree, and at n'great distance a fine overarching cavern
sacred t'the nymphs wh'are called Naiads.113 There are mixing bowls
within it and wine-jars of stone, and the bees hive there. Moreover,
there are great looms of stone on which the nymphs weave their robes of
sea purple—very curious t'see—and at all times there is water within
it. It has tw'entrances, one facing North by which mortals can g'down
int'the cave, while the other comes from the South and is more
mysterious; mortals cannot possibly get in by it, it is the way taken
by the gods.
Int'this harbour, then, they took their ship, for they knew the
place.114 She had s'much way upon her that she ran half her own length
on t'the shore;115 when, however, they had landed, the first thing
they did was t'lift Ulysses with his rug and linen sheet out of the
ship, and lay him down upon the sand still fast asleep. Then they took
out the presents which Minerva had persuaded the Phaeacians t'give him
when he was setting out on his voyage homewards. They put these all
together by the root of the olive tree, away from the road, for fear
some passer by116 might come and steal them before Ulysses awoke; and
then they made the best of their way home again.
But Neptune did not forget the threats with which he had already
threatened Ulysses, s'he took counsel with Jove. "Father Jove," said
he, "I shall n'longer be held in any sort of respect among you gods,
if mortals like the Phaeacians, wh'are my own flesh and blood, show
such small regard for me. I said I would let Ulysses get home when he
had suffered sufficiently. I did not say that he should never get home
at all, for I knew you had already nodded your head about it, and
promised that he should d'so; but now they have brought him in a ship
fast asleep and have landed him in Ithaca after loading him with more
magnificent presents of bronze, gold, and raiment than he would ever
have brought back from Troy, if he had had his share of the spoil and
got home without misadventure."
And Jove answered, "What, 'Lord of the Earthquake, are you talking
about? The gods are by n'means wanting in respect for you. It would be
monstrous were they t'insult one s'old and honoured as you are. As
regards mortals, however, if any of them is indulging in insolence and
treating you disrespectfully, it will always rest with yourself t'deal
with him as you may think proper, s'd'just as you please."
"I should have done s'at once," replied Neptune, "if I were not
anxious t'avoid anything that might displease you; now, therefore, I
should like t'wreck the Phaeacian ship as it is returning from its
escort. This will stop them from escorting people in future; and I
should als'like t'bury their city under a huge mountain."
"My good friend," answered Jove, "I should recommend you at the very
moment when the people from the city are watching the ship on her way,
t'turn it int'a rock near the land and looking like a ship. This will
astonish everybody, and you can then bury their city under the
mountain."
When earth-encircling Neptune heard this he went t'Scheria where the
Phaeacians live, and stayed there till the ship, which was making rapid
way, had got close in. Then he went up t'it, turned it int'stone, and
drove it down with the flat of his hand s'as t'root it in the ground.
After this he went away.
The Phaeacians then began talking among themselves, and one would turn
towards his neighbour, saying, "Bless my heart, wh'is it that can have
rooted the ship in the sea just as she was getting int'port? We could
see the whole of her only a moment ago."
This was how they talked, but they knew nothing about it; and Alcinous
said, "I remember now the old prophecy of my father. He said that
Neptune would be angry with us for taking every one s'safely over the
sea, and would one day wreck a Phaeacian ship as it was returning from
an escort, and bury our city under a high mountain. This was what my
old father used t'say, and now it is all coming true.117 Now therefore
let us all d'as I say; in the first place we must leave off giving
people escorts when they come here, and in the next let us sacrifice
twelve picked bulls t'Neptune that he may have mercy upon us, and not
bury our city under the high mountain." When the people heard this they
were afraid and got ready the bulls.
Thus did the chiefs and rulers of the Phaeacians pray t'king Neptune,
standing round his altar; and at the same time118 Ulysses woke up once
more upon his own soil. He had been s'long away that he did not know
it again; moreover, Jove's daughter Minerva had made it a foggy day, so
that people might not know of his having come, and that she might tell

characters.name: Divine Retribution
characters.importance_exp: This theme drives the conflict between Neptune and the Phaeacians.
characters.quote: I shall n'longer be held in any sort of respect among you gods, if mortals like the Phaeacians, wh'are my own flesh and blood, show such small regard for me.

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' return to Ithaca is a pivotal moment in the narrative.
characters.quote: Ulysses woke up once more upon his own soil.

characters.name: Prophecy Fulfillment
characters.importance_exp: The prophecy foreshadows the consequences of the Phaeacians' actions.
characters.quote: I remember now the old prophecy of my father. He said that Neptune would be angry with us for taking every one s'safely over the sea.

characters.name: Struggle For Control
characters.importance_exp: Neptune's control over the sea illustrates the theme of nature's dominance.
characters.quote: I should like t'wreck the Phaeacian ship as it is returning from its escort.

scenes.title: Ulysses Meets Minerva
scenes.summary: Ulysses encounters Minerva disguised as a shepherd.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to a secluded area in Ithaca.
scenes.text:
the sounding sea bewailing his hard fate. Then Minerva came up t'him
disguised as a young shepherd of delicate and princely mien, with a
good cloak folded double about her shoulders; she had sandals on her
comely feet and held a javelin in her hand. Ulysses was glad when he
saw her, and went straight up t'her.
"My friend," said he, "you are the first person whom I have met with in
this country; I salute you, therefore, and beg you t'be well disposed
towards me. Protect these my goods, and myself too, for I embrace your
knees and pray t'you as though you were a god. Tell me, then, and tell
me truly, what land and country is this? Wh'are its inhabitants? Am I
on an island, or is this the sea board of some continent?"
Minerva answered, "Stranger, you must be very simple, or must have come
from somewhere a long way off, not t'know what country this is. It is
a very celebrated place, and everybody knows it East and West. It is
rugged and not a good driving country, but it is by n'means a bad
island for what there is of it. It grows any quantity of corn and also
wine, for it is watered both by rain and dew; it breeds cattle als'and
goats; all kinds of timber grow here, and there are watering places
where the water never runs dry; so, sir, the name of Ithaca is known
even as far as Troy, which I understand t'be a long way off from this
Achaean country."
Ulysses was glad at finding himself, as Minerva told him, in his own
country, and he began t'answer, but he did not speak the truth, and
made up a lying story in the instinctive wiliness of his heart.
"I heard of Ithaca," said he, "when I was in Crete beyond the seas, and
now it seems I have reached it with all these treasures. I have left as
much more behind me for my children, but am flying because I killed
Orsilochus son of Idomeneus, the fleetest runner in Crete. I killed him
because he wanted t'rob me of the spoils I had got from Troy with so
much trouble and danger both on the field of battle and by the waves of
the weary sea; he said I had not served his father loyally at Troy as
vassal, but had set myself up as an independent ruler, s'I lay in wait
for him with one of my followers by the road side, and speared him as
he was coming int'town from the country. It was a very dark night and
nobody saw us; it was not known, therefore, that I had killed him, but
as soon as I had done s'I went t'a ship and besought the owners, who
were Phoenicians, t'take me on board and set me in Pylos or in Elis
where the Epeans rule, giving them as much spoil as satisfied them.
They meant n'guile, but the wind drove them off their course, and we
sailed on till we came hither by night. It was all we could d't'get
inside the harbour, and none of us said a word about supper though we
wanted it badly, but we all went on shore and lay down just as we were.
I was very tired and fell asleep directly, s'they took my goods out of
the ship, and placed them beside me where I was lying upon the sand.
Then they sailed away t'Sidonia, and I was left here in great distress
of mind."
Such was his story, but Minerva smiled and caressed him with her hand.
Then she took the form of a woman, fair, stately, and wise, "He must be
indeed a shifty lying fellow," said she, "wh'could surpass you in all
manner of craft even though you had a god for your antagonist. Dare
devil that you are, full of guile, unwearying in deceit, can you not
drop your tricks and your instinctive falsehood, even now that you are
in your own country again? We will say n'more, however, about this,
for we can both of us deceive upon occasion—you are the most
accomplished counsellor and orator among all mankind, while I for
diplomacy and subtlety have n'equal among the gods. Did you not know
Jove's daughter Minerva—me, wh'have been ever with you, wh'kept watch
over you in all your troubles, and wh'made the Phaeacians take so
great a liking t'you? And now, again, I am come here t'talk things
over with you, and help you t'hide the treasure I made the Phaeacians
give you; I want t'tell you about the troubles that await you in your
own house; you have got t'face them, but tell n'one, neither man nor
woman, that you have come home again. Bear everything, and put up with
every man's insolence, without a word."
And Ulysses answered, "A man, goddess, may know a great deal, but you
are s'constantly changing your appearance that when he meets you it is
a hard matter for him t'know whether it is you or not. This much,
however, I know exceedingly well; you were very kind t'me as long as
we Achaeans were fighting before Troy, but from the day on which we
went on board ship after having sacked the city of Priam, and heaven
dispersed us—from that day, Minerva, I saw n'more of you, and cannot
ever remember your coming t'my ship t'help me in a difficulty; I had
t'wander on sick and sorry till the gods delivered me from evil and I
reached the city of the Phaeacians, where you encouraged me and took me
int'the town.120 And now, I beseech you in your father's name, tell me
the truth, for I d'not believe I am really back in Ithaca. I am in
some other country and you are mocking me and deceiving me in all you
have been saying. Tell me then truly, have I really got back t'my own
country?"
"You are always taking something of that sort in your head," replied
Minerva, "and that is why I cannot desert you in your afflictions; you
are s'plausible, shrewd and shifty. Any one but yourself on returning
from s'long a voyage would at once have gone home t'see his wife and
children, but you d'not seem t'care about asking after them or
hearing any news about them till you have exploited your wife, who
remains at home vainly grieving for you, and having n'peace night or
day for the tears she sheds on your behalf. As for my not coming near
you, I was never uneasy about you, for I was certain you would get back
safely though you would lose all your men, and I did not wish to
quarrel with my uncle Neptune, wh'never forgave you for having blinded
his son.121 I will now, however, point out t'you the lie of the land,
and you will then perhaps believe me. This is the haven of the old
merman Phorcys, and here is the olive tree that grows at the head of
it; [near it is the cave sacred t'the Naiads;122 here to'is the
overarching cavern in which you have offered many an acceptable
hecatomb t'the nymphs, and this is the wooded mountain Neritum."
As she spoke the goddess dispersed the mist and the land appeared. Then
Ulysses rejoiced at finding himself again in his own land, and kissed
the bounteous soil; he lifted up his hands and prayed t'the nymphs,
saying, "Naiad nymphs, daughters of Jove, I made sure that I was never
again t'see you, now therefore I greet you with all loving
salutations, and I will bring you offerings as in the old days, if
Jove's redoubtable daughter will grant me life, and bring my son to
manhood."
"Take heart, and d'not trouble yourself about that," rejoined Minerva,
"let us rather set about stowing your things at once in the cave, where
they will be quite safe. Let us see how we can best manage it all."

characters.name: Disguise And Deception
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses struggles with his identity and the truth of his situation.
characters.quote: “I am in some other country and you are mocking me and deceiving me in all you have been saying.”

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Minerva's role as a guide is crucial for Ulysses' return.
characters.quote: “I am come here t'talk things over with you, and help you t'hide the treasure I made the Phaeacians give you.”

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' return to Ithaca is a pivotal moment in the narrative.
characters.quote: “Ulysses rejoiced at finding himself again in his own land, and kissed the bounteous soil.”

characters.name: Cunning And Strategy
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' cleverness is highlighted through his deceptive storytelling.
characters.quote: “He must be indeed a shifty lying fellow,” said she, “wh'could surpass you in all manner of craft.”

scenes.title: Planning Revenge
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Minerva devise a plan against the suitors.
scenes.explanation: Location remains in Ithaca, but focus shifts to planning.
scenes.text:
consulted how t'compass the destruction of the wicked suitors.
"Ulysses," said Minerva, "noble son of Laertes, think how you can lay
hands on these disreputable people wh'have been lording it in your
house these three years, courting your wife and making wedding presents
t'her, while she does nothing but lament your absence, giving hope and
sending encouraging messages123 t'every one of them, but meaning the
very opposite of all she says."
And Ulysses answered, "In good truth, goddess, it seems I should have
come t'much the same bad end in my own house as Agamemnon did, if you
had not given me such timely information. Advise me how I shall best
avenge myself. Stand by my side and put your courage int'my heart as
on the day when we loosed Troy's fair diadem from her brow. Help me now
as you did then, and I will fight three hundred men, if you, goddess,
will be with me."
"Trust me for that," said she, "I will not lose sight of you when once
we set about it, and I imagine that some of those wh'are devouring
your substance will then bespatter the pavement with their blood and
brains. I will begin by disguising you s'that n'human being shall
know you; I will cover your body with wrinkles; you shall lose all your
yellow hair; I will clothe you in a garment that shall fill all wh'see
it with loathing; I will blear your fine eyes for you, and make you an
unseemly object in the sight of the suitors, of your wife, and of the
son whom you left behind you. Then g'at once t'the swineherd wh'is
in charge of your pigs; he has been always well affected towards you,
and is devoted t'Penelope and your son; you will find him feeding his
pigs near the rock that is called Raven124 by the fountain Arethusa,
where they are fattening on beechmast and spring water after their
manner. Stay with him and find out how things are going, while I
proceed t'Sparta and see your son, wh'is with Menelaus at Lacedaemon,
where he has gone t'try and find out whether you are still alive."125
"But why," said Ulysses, "did you not tell him, for you knew all about
it? Did you want him to't'g'sailing about amid all kinds of hardship
while others are eating up his estate?"
Minerva answered, "Never mind about him, I sent him that he might be
well spoken of for having gone. He is in n'sort of difficulty, but is
staying quite comfortably with Menelaus, and is surrounded with
abundance of every kind. The suitors have put out t'sea and are lying
in wait for him, for they mean t'kill him before he can get home. I do
not much think they will succeed, but rather that some of those wh'are
now eating up your estate will first find a grave themselves."
As she spoke Minerva touched him with her wand and covered him with
wrinkles, took away all his yellow hair, and withered the flesh over
his whole body; she bleared his eyes, which were naturally very fine
ones; she changed his clothes and threw an old rag of a wrap about him,
and a tunic, tattered, filthy, and begrimed with smoke; she als'gave
him an undressed deer skin as an outer garment, and furnished him with
a staff and a wallet all in holes, with a twisted thong for him to
sling it over his shoulder.
When the pair had thus laid their plans they parted, and the goddess

characters.importance_exp: Central to Ulysses' motivation in this scene
characters.quote: Advise me how I shall best avenge myself.

characters.importance_exp: Key strategy for Ulysses' return
characters.quote: I will cover your body with wrinkles; you shall lose all your yellow hair; I will clothe you in a garment that shall fill all wh'see it with loathing;

scenes.title: Ulysses Arrives at Eumaeus' Hut
scenes.summary: Ulysses reaches the swineherd's hut after a long journey.
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES IN THE HUT WITH EUMAEUS.
Ulysses now left the haven, and took the rough track up through the
wooded country and over the crest of the mountain till he reached the
place where Minerva had said that he would find the swineherd, wh'was
the most thrifty servant he had. He found him sitting in front of his
hut, which was by the yards that he had built on a site which could be
seen from far. He had made them spacious126 and fair t'see, with a
free run for the pigs all round them; he had built them during his
master's absence, of stones which he had gathered out of the ground,
without saying anything t'Penelope or Laertes, and he had fenced them
on top with thorn bushes. Outside the yard he had run a strong fence of
oaken posts, split, and set pretty close together, while inside he had
built twelve styes near one another for the sows t'lie in. There were
fifty pigs wallowing in each stye, all of them breeding sows; but the
boars slept outside and were much fewer in number, for the suitors kept
on eating them, and the swineherd had t'send them the best he had
continually. There were three hundred and sixty boar pigs, and the
herdsman's four hounds, which were as fierce as wolves, slept always
with them. The swineherd was at that moment cutting out a pair of
sandals127 from a good stout ox hide. Three of his men were out herding
the pigs in one place or another, and he had sent the fourth t'town
with a boar that he had been forced t'send the suitors that they might
sacrifice it and have their fill of meat.
When the hounds saw Ulysses they set up a furious barking and flew at
him, but Ulysses was cunning enough t'sit down and loose his hold of
the stick that he had in his hand: still, he would have been torn by
them in his own homestead had not the swineherd dropped his ox hide,
rushed full speed through the gate of the yard and driven the dogs off
by shouting and throwing stones at them. Then he said t'Ulysses, "Old
man, the dogs were likely t'have made short work of you, and then you
would have got me int'trouble. The gods have given me quite enough
worries without that, for I have lost the best of masters, and am in
continual grief on his account. I have t'attend swine for other people
t'eat, while he, if he yet lives t'see the light of day, is starving
in some distant land. But come inside, and when you have had your fill
of bread and wine, tell me where you come from, and all about your
misfortunes."

characters.name: Loyalty And Care
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus shows unwavering loyalty to Ulysses despite his absence.
characters.quote: I have lost the best of masters, and am in continual grief on his account.

characters.name: Enduring Suffering
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus expresses his own suffering due to Ulysses' absence.
characters.quote: I have t'attend swine for other people t'eat, while he, if he yet lives t'see the light of day, is starving in some distant land.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus offers hospitality to Ulysses, showcasing his character.
characters.quote: But come inside, and when you have had your fill of bread and wine, tell me where you come from, and all about your misfortunes.

scenes.title: Inside the Hut
scenes.summary: Ulysses is welcomed into the hut by Eumaeus.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to inside the hut.
scenes.text:
On this the swineherd led the way int'the hut and bade him sit down.
He strewed a good thick bed of rushes upon the floor, and on the top of
this he threw the shaggy chamois skin—a great thick one—on which he
used t'sleep by night. Ulysses was pleased at being made thus welcome,
and said "May Jove, sir, and the rest of the gods grant you your
heart's desire in return for the kind way in which you have received
me."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Stranger, though a still
poorer man should come here, it would not be right for me t'insult
him, for all strangers and beggars are from Jove. You must take what
you can get and be thankful, for servants live in fear when they have
young lords for their masters; and this is my misfortune now, for
heaven has hindered the return of him wh'would have been always good
t'me and given me something of my own—a house, a piece of land, a good
looking wife, and all else that a liberal master allows a servant who
has worked hard for him, and whose labour the gods have prospered as
they have mine in the situation which I hold. If my master had grown
old here he would have done great things by me, but he is gone, and I
wish that Helen's whole race were utterly destroyed, for she has been
the death of many a good man. It was this matter that took my master to
Ilius, the land of noble steeds, t'fight the Trojans in the cause of
king Agamemnon."
As he spoke he bound his girdle round him and went t'the styes where
the young sucking pigs were penned. He picked out tw'which he brought
back with him and sacrificed. He singed them, cut them up, and spitted
them; when the meat was cooked he brought it all in and set it before
Ulysses, hot and still on the spit, whereon Ulysses sprinkled it over
with white barley meal. The swineherd then mixed wine in a bowl of
ivy-wood, and taking a seat opposite Ulysses told him t'begin.
"Fall to, stranger," said he, "on a dish of servant's pork. The fat
pigs have t'g't'the suitors, wh'eat them up without shame or
scruple; but the blessed gods love not such shameful doings, and
respect those wh'd'what is lawful and right. Even the fierce
freebooters wh'g'raiding on other people's land, and Jove gives them
their spoil—even they, when they have filled their ships and got home
again live conscience-stricken, and look fearfully for judgement; but
some god seems t'have told these people that Ulysses is dead and gone;
they will not, therefore, g'back t'their own homes and make their
offers of marriage in the usual way, but waste his estate by force,
without fear or stint. Not a day or night comes out of heaven, but they
sacrifice not one victim nor tw'only, and they take the run of his
wine, for he was exceedingly rich. N'other great man either in Ithaca
or on the mainland is as rich as he was; he had as much as twenty men
put together. I will tell you what he had. There are twelve herds of
cattle upon the main land, and as many flocks of sheep, there are also
twelve droves of pigs, while his own men and hired strangers feed him
twelve widely spreading herds of goats. Here in Ithaca he runs even
large flocks of goats on the far end of the island, and they are in the
charge of excellent goat herds. Each one of these sends the suitors the
best goat in the flock every day. As for myself, I am in charge of the
pigs that you see here, and I have t'keep picking out the best I have
and sending it t'them."
This was his story, but Ulysses went on eating and drinking ravenously

characters.quote: May Jove, sir, and the rest of the gods grant you your heart's desire in return for the kind way in which you have received me.

characters.name: Loyalty And Care

characters.quote: if my master had grown old here he would have done great things by me, but he is gone

characters.name: Vengeance

characters.quote: the blessed gods love not such shameful doings, and respect those wh'd'what is lawful and right.

characters.name: Loss And Absence
characters.importance_exp: The swineherd expresses his feelings of loss regarding Ulysses and the state of Ithaca.
characters.quote: I wish that Helen's whole race were utterly destroyed, for she has been the death of many a good man.

scenes.title: Eumaeus' Story
scenes.summary: Eumaeus shares his thoughts on Ulysses and his misfortunes.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses begins to tell his story.
scenes.text:
without a word, brooding his revenge. When he had eaten enough and was
satisfied, the swineherd took the bowl from which he usually drank,
filled it with wine, and gave it t'Ulysses, wh'was pleased, and said
as he took it in his hands, "My friend, wh'was this master of yours
that bought you and paid for you, s'rich and s'powerful as you tell
me? You say he perished in the cause of King Agamemnon; tell me wh'he
was, in case I may have met with such a person. Jove and the other gods
know, but I may be able t'give you news of him, for I have travelled
much."
Eumaeus answered, "Old man, n'traveller wh'comes here with news will
get Ulysses' wife and son t'believe his story. Nevertheless, tramps in
want of a lodging keep coming with their mouths full of lies, and not a
word of truth; every one wh'finds his way t'Ithaca goes t'my
mistress and tells her falsehoods, whereon she takes them in, makes
much of them, and asks them all manner of questions, crying all the
time as women will when they have lost their husbands. And you too, old
man, for a shirt and a cloak would doubtless make up a very pretty
story. But the wolves and birds of prey have long since torn Ulysses to
pieces, or the fishes of the sea have eaten him, and his bones are
lying buried deep in sand upon some foreign shore; he is dead and gone,
and a bad business it is for all his friends—for me especially; go
where I may I shall never find s'good a master, not even if I were to
g'home t'my mother and father where I was bred and born. I d'not so
much care, however, about my parents now, though I should dearly like
t'see them again in my own country; it is the loss of Ulysses that
grieves me most; I cannot speak of him without reverence though he is
here n'longer, for he was very fond of me, and took such care of me
that wherever he may be I shall always honour his memory."
"My friend," replied Ulysses, "you are very positive, and very hard of
belief about your master's coming home again, nevertheless I will not
merely say, but will swear, that he is coming. D'not give me anything
for my news till he has actually come, you may then give me a shirt and
cloak of good wear if you will. I am in great want, but I will not take
anything at all till then, for I hate a man, even as I hate hell fire,
wh'lets his poverty tempt him int'lying. I swear by king Jove, by the
rites of hospitality, and by that hearth of Ulysses t'which I have now
come, that all will surely happen as I have said it will. Ulysses will
return in this self same year; with the end of this moon and the
beginning of the next he will be here t'd'vengeance on all those who
are ill treating his wife and son."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Old man, you will neither
get paid for bringing good news, nor will Ulysses ever come home; drink
your wine in peace, and let us talk about something else. D'not keep
on reminding me of all this; it always pains me when any one speaks
about my honoured master. As for your oath we will let it alone, but I
only wish he may come, as d'Penelope, his old father Laertes, and his
son Telemachus. I am terribly unhappy to'about this same boy of his;
he was running up fast int'manhood, and bade fare t'be n'worse man,
face and figure, than his father, but some one, either god or man, has
been unsettling his mind, s'he has gone off t'Pylos t'try and get
news of his father, and the suitors are lying in wait for him as he is
coming home, in the hope of leaving the house of Arceisius without a
name in Ithaca. But let us say n'more about him, and leave him t'be
taken, or else t'escape if the son of Saturn holds his hand over him
t'protect him. And now, old man, tell me your own story; tell me also,
for I want t'know, wh'you are and where you come from. Tell me of
your town and parents, what manner of ship you came in, how crew
brought you t'Ithaca, and from what country they professed t'come—for

characters.name: Loyalty And Care
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Eumaeus' character and his feelings about Ulysses.
characters.quote: I cannot speak of him without reverence though he is here n'longer, for he was very fond of me, and took such care of me that wherever he may be I shall always honour his memory.

characters.name: Loss Of Hope
characters.importance_exp: The tension between hope for Ulysses' return and despair over his absence is palpable.
characters.quote: I swear by king Jove, by the rites of hospitality, and by that hearth of Ulysses t'which I have now come, that all will surely happen as I have said it will.

characters.name: Truth And Deceit
characters.importance_exp: The theme reflects the struggle between truth and the lies told by others about Ulysses.
characters.quote: Nevertheless, tramps in want of a lodging keep coming with their mouths full of lies, and not a word of truth; every one wh'finds his way t'Ithaca goes t'my mistress and tells her falsehoods.

scenes.title: Ulysses' Tale of Woe
scenes.summary: Ulysses recounts his past adventures and hardships.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses continues his story.
scenes.text:
you cannot have come by land."
And Ulysses answered, "I will tell you all about it. If there were meat
and wine enough, and we could stay here in the hut with nothing t'do
but t'eat and drink while the others g't'their work, I could easily
talk on for a whole twelve months without ever finishing the story of
the sorrows with which it has pleased heaven t'visit me.
"I am by birth a Cretan; my father was a well t'd'man, wh'had many
sons born in marriage, whereas I was the son of a slave whom he had
purchased for a concubine; nevertheless, my father Castor son of Hylax
(whose lineage I claim, and wh'was held in the highest honour among
the Cretans for his wealth, prosperity, and the valour of his sons) put
me on the same level with my brothers wh'had been born in wedlock.
When, however, death took him t'the house of Hades, his sons divided
his estate and cast lots for their shares, but t'me they gave a
holding and little else; nevertheless, my valour enabled me t'marry
int'a rich family, for I was not given t'bragging, or shirking on the
field of battle. It is all over now; still, if you look at the straw
you can see what the ear was, for I have had trouble enough and to
spare. Mars and Minerva made me doughty in war; when I had picked my
men t'surprise the enemy with an ambuscade I never gave death s'much
as a thought, but was the first t'leap forward and spear all whom I
could overtake. Such was I in battle, but I did not care about farm
work, nor the frugal home life of those wh'would bring up children. My
delight was in ships, fighting, javelins, and arrows—things that most
men shudder t'think of; but one man likes one thing and another
another, and this was what I was most naturally inclined to. Before the
Achaeans went t'Troy, nine times was I in command of men and ships on
foreign service, and I amassed much wealth. I had my pick of the spoil
in the first instance, and much more was allotted t'me later on.
"My house grew apace and I became a great man among the Cretans, but
when Jove counselled that terrible expedition, in which s'many
perished, the people required me and Idomeneus t'lead their ships to
Troy, and there was n'way out of it, for they insisted on our doing
so. There we fought for nine whole years, but in the tenth we sacked
the city of Priam and sailed home again as heaven dispersed us. Then it
was that Jove devised evil against me. I spent but one month happily
with my children, wife, and property, and then I conceived the idea of
making a descent on Egypt, s'I fitted out a fine fleet and manned it.
I had nine ships, and the people flocked t'fill them. For six days I
and my men made feast, and I found them many victims both for sacrifice
t'the gods and for themselves, but on the seventh day we went on board
and set sail from Crete with a fair North wind behind us though we were
going down a river. Nothing went ill with any of our ships, and we had
n'sickness on board, but sat where we were and let the ships g'as the
wind and steersmen took them. On the fifth day we reached the river
Aegyptus; there I stationed my ships in the river, bidding my men stay
by them and keep guard over them while I sent out scouts t'reconnoitre
from every point of vantage.
"But the men disobeyed my orders, took t'their own devices, and
ravaged the land of the Egyptians, killing the men, and taking their
wives and children captive. The alarm was soon carried t'the city, and
when they heard the war cry, the people came out at daybreak till the
plain was filled with horsemen and foot soldiers and with the gleam of
armour. Then Jove spread panic among my men, and they would n'longer
face the enemy, for they found themselves surrounded. The Egyptians
killed many of us, and took the rest alive t'd'forced labour for
them. Jove, however, put it in my mind t'd'thus—and I wish I had died
then and there in Egypt instead, for there was much sorrow in store for
me—I took off my helmet and shield and dropped my spear from my hand;
then I went straight up t'the king's chariot, clasped his knees and
kissed them, whereon he spared my life, bade me get int'his chariot,
and took me weeping t'his own home. Many made at me with their ashen
spears and tried t'kill me in their fury, but the king protected me,
for he feared the wrath of Jove the protector of strangers, who
punishes those wh'd'evil.
"I stayed there for seven years and got together much money among the
Egyptians, for they all gave me something; but when it was now going on
for eight years there came a certain Phoenician, a cunning rascal, who
had already committed all sorts of villainy, and this man talked me
over int'going with him t'Phoenicia, where his house and his
possessions lay. I stayed there for a whole twelve months, but at the
end of that time when months and days had gone by till the same season
had come round again, he set me on board a ship bound for Libya, on a
pretence that I was t'take a carg'along with him t'that place, but
really that he might sell me as a slave and take the money I fetched. I
suspected his intention, but went on board with him, for I could not
help it.
"The ship ran before a fresh North wind till we had reached the sea
that lies between Crete and Libya; there, however, Jove counselled
their destruction, for as soon as we were well out from Crete and could
see nothing but sea and sky, he raised a black cloud over our ship and
the sea grew dark beneath it. Then Jove let fly with his thunderbolts
and the ship went round and round and was filled with fire and
brimstone as the lightning struck it. The men fell all int'the sea;
they were carried about in the water round the ship looking like so
many sea-gulls, but the god presently deprived them of all chance of
getting home again. I was all dismayed. Jove, however, sent the ship's
mast within my reach, which saved my life, for I clung t'it, and
drifted before the fury of the gale. Nine days did I drift but in the
darkness of the tenth night a great wave bore me on t'the Thesprotian
coast. There Pheidon king of the Thesprotians entertained me hospitably
without charging me anything at all—for his son found me when I was
nearly dead with cold and fatigue, whereon he raised me by the hand,
took me t'his father's house and gave me clothes t'wear.
"There it was that I heard news of Ulysses, for the king told me he had
entertained him, and shown him much hospitality while he was on his
homeward journey. He showed me als'the treasure of gold, and wrought
iron that Ulysses had got together. There was enough t'keep his family
for ten generations, s'much had he left in the house of king Pheidon.
But the king said Ulysses had gone t'Dodona that he might learn Jove's
mind from the god's high oak tree, and know whether after s'long an
absence he should return t'Ithaca openly, or in secret. Moreover the
king swore in my presence, making drink-offerings in his own house as
he did so, that the ship was by the water side, and the crew found,
that should take him t'his own country. He sent me off however before
Ulysses returned, for there happened t'be a Thesprotian ship sailing
for the wheat-growing island of Dulichium, and he told those in charge
of her t'be sure and take me safely t'King Acastus.
"These men hatched a plot against me that would have reduced me t'the
very extreme of misery, for when the ship had got some way out from
land they resolved on selling me as a slave. They stripped me of the
shirt and cloak that I was wearing, and gave me instead the tattered
old clouts in which you now see me; then, towards nightfall, they
reached the tilled lands of Ithaca, and there they bound me with a
strong rope fast in the ship, while they went on shore t'get supper by
the sea side. But the gods soon undid my bonds for me, and having drawn
my rags over my head I slid down the rudder int'the sea, where I
struck out and swam till I was well clear of them, and came ashore near
a thick wood in which I lay concealed. They were very angry at my
having escaped and went searching about for me, till at last they
thought it was n'further use and went back t'their ship. The gods,
having hidden me thus easily, then took me t'a good man's door—for it

characters.name: Enduring Suffering
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Ulysses' narrative of his hardships.
characters.quote: I could easily talk on for a whole twelve months without ever finishing the story of the sorrows with which it has pleased heaven t'visit me.

characters.name: Heroism And Strength
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses reflects on his past bravery and accomplishments.
characters.quote: Mars and Minerva made me doughty in war; when I had picked my men t'surprise the enemy with an ambuscade I never gave death s'much as a thought.

characters.name: Betrayal And Trust
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses recounts the betrayal by his men and the cunning of others.
characters.quote: But the men disobeyed my orders, took t'their own devices, and ravaged the land of the Egyptians, killing the men, and taking their wives and children captive.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The gods play a significant role in Ulysses' journey and fate.
characters.quote: Jove, however, put it in my mind t'd'thus—and I wish I had died then and there in Egypt instead, for there was much sorrow in store for me.

scenes.title: Eumaeus' Doubts
scenes.summary: Eumaeus expresses skepticism about Ulysses' return.
scenes.explanation: Eumaeus responds to Ulysses' tale.
scenes.text:
seems that I am not t'die yet awhile."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Poor unhappy stranger, I
have found the story of your misfortunes extremely interesting, but
that part about Ulysses is not right; and you will never get me to
believe it. Why should a man like you g'about telling lies in this
way? I know all about the return of my master. The gods one and all of
them detest him, or they would have taken him before Troy, or let him
die with friends around him when the days of his fighting were done;
for then the Achaeans would have built a mound over his ashes and his
son would have been heir t'his renown, but now the storm winds have
spirited him away we know not whither.
"As for me I live out of the way here with the pigs, and never g'to
the town unless when Penelope sends for me on the arrival of some news
about Ulysses. Then they all sit round and ask questions, both those
wh'grieve over the king's absence, and those wh'rejoice at it because
they can eat up his property without paying for it. For my own part I
have never cared about asking anyone else since the time when I was
taken in by an Aetolian, wh'had killed a man and come a long way till
at last he reached my station, and I was very kind t'him. He said he
had seen Ulysses with Idomeneus among the Cretans, refitting his ships
which had been damaged in a gale. He said Ulysses would return in the
following summer or autumn with his men, and that he would bring back
much wealth. And now you, you unfortunate old man, since fate has
brought you t'my door, d'not try t'flatter me in this way with vain
hopes. It is not for any such reason that I shall treat you kindly, but
only out of respect for Jove the god of hospitality, as fearing him and
pitying you."

characters.name: Loss Of Hope
characters.importance_exp: Hope is contrasted with despair in Eumaeus' words.
characters.quote: I know all about the return of my master. The gods one and all of them detest him, or they would have taken him before Troy...

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus shows kindness despite his own suffering.
characters.quote: It is not for any such reason that I shall treat you kindly, but only out of respect for Jove the god of hospitality...

scenes.title: The Bargain
scenes.summary: Ulysses proposes a bargain regarding his news.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses makes a deal with Eumaeus.
scenes.text:
Ulysses answered, "I see that you are of an unbelieving mind; I have
given you my oath, and yet you will not credit me; let us then make a
bargain, and call all the gods in heaven t'witness it. If your master
comes home, give me a cloak and shirt of good wear, and send me to
Dulichium where I want t'go; but if he does not come as I say he will,
set your men on t'me, and tell them t'throw me from yonder precipice,
as a warning t'tramps not t'g'about the country telling lies."
"And a pretty figure I should cut then," replied Eumaeus, "both now and
hereafter, if I were t'kill you after receiving you int'my hut and
showing you hospitality. I should have t'say my prayers in good
earnest if I did; but it is just supper time and I hope my men will
come in directly, that we may cook something savoury for supper."
Thus did they converse, and presently the swineherds came up with the

characters.name: Betrayal And Trust
characters.importance_exp: Trust is crucial in their bargain.
characters.quote: I have given you my oath, and yet you will not credit me; let us then make a bargain, and call all the gods in heaven t'witness it.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Hospitality is a key value in their interaction.
characters.quote: I should have t'say my prayers in good earnest if I did; but it is just supper time and I hope my men will come in directly, that we may cook something savoury for supper.

scenes.title: Preparing for Supper
scenes.summary: Eumaeus prepares a pig for supper as night falls.
scenes.explanation: The scene shifts to supper preparations.
scenes.text:
pigs, which were then shut up for the night in their styes, and a
tremendous squealing they made as they were being driven int'them. But
Eumaeus called t'his men and said, "Bring in the best pig you have,
that I may sacrifice him for this stranger, and we will take toll of
him ourselves. We have had trouble enough this long time feeding pigs,
while others reap the fruit of our labour."
On this he began chopping firewood, while the others brought in a fine
fat five year old boar pig, and set it at the altar. Eumaeus did not
forget the gods, for he was a man of good principles, s'the first
thing he did was t'cut bristles from the pig's face and throw them
int'the fire, praying t'all the gods as he did s'that Ulysses might
return home again. Then he clubbed the pig with a billet of oak which
he had kept back when he was chopping the firewood, and stunned it,
while the others slaughtered and singed it. Then they cut it up, and
Eumaeus began by putting raw pieces from each joint on t'some of the
fat; these he sprinkled with barley meal, and laid upon the embers;
they cut the rest of the meat up small, put the pieces upon the spits
and roasted them till they were done; when they had taken them off the
spits they threw them on t'the dresser in a heap. The swineherd, who
was a most equitable man, then stood up t'give every one his share. He
made seven portions; one of these he set apart for Mercury the son of
Maia and the nymphs, praying t'them as he did so; the others he dealt
out t'the men man by man. He gave Ulysses some slices cut lengthways
down the loin as a mark of especial honour, and Ulysses was much
pleased. "I hope, Eumaeus," said he, "that Jove will be as well
disposed towards you as I am, for the respect you are showing t'an
outcast like myself."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Eat, my good fellow, and
enjoy your supper, such as it is. God grants this, and withholds that,
just as he thinks right, for he can d'whatever he chooses."
As he spoke he cut off the first piece and offered it as a burnt
sacrifice t'the immortal gods; then he made them a drink-offering, put
the cup in the hands of Ulysses, and sat down t'his own portion.
Mesaulius brought them their bread; the swineherd had brought this man
on his own account from among the Taphians during his master's absence,
and had paid for him with his own money without saying anything either
t'his mistress or Laertes. They then laid their hands upon the good
things that were before them, and when they had had enough t'eat and
drink, Mesaulius took away what was left of the bread, and they all
went t'bed after having made a hearty supper.

characters.importance_exp: Central to the scene as Eumaeus shows kindness to Ulysses.

characters.quote: Eumaeus did not forget the gods, for he was a man of good principles, s'the first thing he did was t'cut bristles from the pig's face and throw them int'the fire, praying t'all the gods as he did s'that Ulysses might return home again.
