scenes.title: Nighttime and Rest
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Eumaeus settle down for the night.
scenes.explanation: The location remains in the hut as they prepare for sleep.
scenes.text:
Now the night came on stormy and very dark, for there was n'moon. It
poured without ceasing, and the wind blew strong from the West, which
is a wet quarter, s'Ulysses thought he would see whether Eumaeus, in
the excellent care he took of him, would take off his own cloak and
give it him, or make one of his men give him one. "Listen t'me," said
he, "Eumaeus and the rest of you; when I have said a prayer I will tell
you something. It is the wine that makes me talk in this way; wine will
make even a wise man fall t'singing; it will make him chuckle and
dance and say many a word that he had better leave unspoken; still, as
I have begun, I will g'on. Would that I were still young and strong as
when we got up an ambuscade before Troy. Menelaus and Ulysses were the
leaders, but I was in command also, for the other tw'would have it so.
When we had come up t'the wall of the city we crouched down beneath
our armour and lay there under cover of the reeds and thick brushwood
that grew about the swamp. It came on t'freeze with a North wind
blowing; the snow fell small and fine like hoar frost, and our shields
were coated thick with rime. The others had all got cloaks and shirts,
and slept comfortably enough with their shields about their shoulders,
but I had carelessly left my cloak behind me, not thinking that I
should be to'cold, and had gone off in nothing but my shirt and
shield. When the night was two-thirds through and the stars had shifted
their places, I nudged Ulysses wh'was close t'me with my elbow, and
he at once gave me his ear.
"'Ulysses,' said I, 'this cold will be the death of me, for I have no
cloak; some god fooled me int'setting off with nothing on but my
shirt, and I d'not know what t'do.'
"Ulysses, wh'was as crafty as he was valiant, hit upon the following
plan:
"'Keep still,' said he in a low voice, 'or the others will hear you.'
Then he raised his head on his elbow.
"'My friends,' said he, 'I have had a dream from heaven in my sleep. We
are a long way from the ships; I wish some one would g'down and tell
Agamemnon t'send us up more men at once.'
"On this Thoas son of Andraemon threw off his cloak and set out running
t'the ships, whereon I took the cloak and lay in it comfortably enough
till morning. Would that I were still young and strong as I was in
those days, for then some one of you swineherds would give me a cloak
both out of good will and for the respect due t'a brave soldier; but
now people look down upon me because my clothes are shabby."
And Eumaeus answered, "Old man, you have told us an excellent story,
and have said nothing s'far but what is quite satisfactory; for the
present, therefore, you shall want neither clothing nor anything else
that a stranger in distress may reasonably expect, but to-morrow
morning you have t'shake your own old rags about your body again, for
we have not many spare cloaks nor shirts up here, but every man has
only one. When Ulysses' son comes home again he will give you both
cloak and shirt, and send you wherever you may want t'go."
With this he got up and made a bed for Ulysses by throwing some
goatskins and sheepskins on the ground in front of the fire. Here
Ulysses lay down, and Eumaeus covered him over with a great heavy cloak
that he kept for a change in case of extraordinarily bad weather.
Thus did Ulysses sleep, and the young men slept beside him. But the
swineherd did not like sleeping away from his pigs, s'he got ready to
g'outside, and Ulysses was glad t'see that he looked after his
property during his master's absence. First he slung his sword over his
brawny shoulders and put on a thick cloak t'keep out the wind. He also
took the skin of a large and well fed goat, and a javelin in case of
attack from men or dogs. Thus equipped he went t'his rest where the
pigs were camping under an overhanging rock that gave them shelter from
the North wind.

characters.name: Nostalgia
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses reflects on his past strength and bravery.
characters.quote: Would that I were still young and strong as I was in those days

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus shows kindness to Ulysses despite his shabby appearance.
characters.quote: you shall want neither clothing nor anything else that a stranger in distress may reasonably expect

characters.name: Survival
characters.importance_exp: The characters prepare for the harsh conditions of the night.
characters.quote: he got up and made a bed for Ulysses by throwing some goatskins and sheepskins on the ground

scenes.title: Minerva's Visit to Telemachus
scenes.summary: Minerva visits Telemachus in Lacedaemon.
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
MINERVA SUMMONS TELEMACHUS FROM LACEDAEMON—HE MEETS WITH THEOCLYMENUS
AT PYLOS AND BRINGS HIM T'ITHACA—ON LANDING HE GOES T'THE HUT OF
EUMAEUS.
But Minerva went t'the fair city of Lacedaemon t'tell Ulysses' son
that he was t'return at once. She found him and Pisistratus sleeping
in the forecourt of Menelaus's house; Pisistratus was fast asleep, but
Telemachus could get n'rest all night for thinking of his unhappy
father, s'Minerva went close up t'him and said:
"Telemachus, you should not remain s'far away from home any longer,
nor leave your property with such dangerous people in your house; they
will eat up everything you have among them, and you will have been on a
fool's errand. Ask Menelaus t'send you home at once if you wish to
find your excellent mother still there when you get back. Her father
and brothers are already urging her t'marry Eurymachus, wh'has given
her more than any of the others, and has been greatly increasing his
wedding presents. I hope nothing valuable may have been taken from the
house in spite of you, but you know what women are—they always want to
d'the best they can for the man wh'marries them, and never give
another thought t'the children of their first husband, nor t'their
father either when he is dead and done with. G'home, therefore, and
put everything in charge of the most respectable woman servant that you
have, until it shall please heaven t'send you a wife of your own. Let
me tell you als'of another matter which you had better attend to. The
chief men among the suitors are lying in wait for you in the Strait128
between Ithaca and Samos, and they mean t'kill you before you can
reach home. I d'not much think they will succeed; it is more likely
that some of those wh'are now eating up your property will find a
grave themselves. Sail night and day, and keep your ship well away from
the islands; the god wh'watches over you and protects you will send
you a fair wind. As soon as you get t'Ithaca send your ship and men on
t'the town, but yourself g'straight t'the swineherd wh'has charge
of your pigs; he is well disposed towards you, stay with him,
therefore, for the night, and then send him t'Penelope t'tell her
that you have got back safe from Pylos."

characters.name: Loyalty And Care
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Telemachus's journey and decisions.
characters.quote: you will have been on a fool's errand.

characters.name: Monstrous Threats
characters.importance_exp: The threats against Telemachus's life are crucial to the scene.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The urgency in the warning about the suitors creates a palpable sense of fear and the need for immediate action.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Minerva's role as a guide highlights the theme of divine intervention.
characters.quote: the god wh'watches over you and protects you will send you a fair wind.

scenes.title: Departure from Lacedaemon
scenes.summary: Telemachus prepares to leave Lacedaemon with Pisistratus.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Menelaus's house.
scenes.text:
Then she went back t'Olympus; but Telemachus stirred Pisistratus with
his heel t'rouse him, and said, "Wake up Pisistratus, and yoke the
horses t'the chariot, for we must set off home."129
But Pisistratus said, "N'matter what hurry we are in we cannot drive
in the dark. It will be morning soon; wait till Menelaus has brought
his presents and put them in the chariot for us; and let him say good
bye t'us in the usual way. S'long as he lives a guest should never
forget a host wh'has shown him kindness."
As he spoke day began t'break, and Menelaus, wh'had already risen,
leaving Helen in bed, came towards them. When Telemachus saw him he put
on his shirt as fast as he could, threw a great cloak over his
shoulders, and went out t'meet him. "Menelaus," said he, "let me go
back now t'my own country, for I want t'get home."
And Menelaus answered, "Telemachus, if you insist on going I will not
detain you. I d'not like t'see a host either to'fond of his guest or
to'rude t'him. Moderation is best in all things, and not letting a
man g'when he wants t'd's'is as bad as telling him t'g'if he
would like t'stay. One should treat a guest well as long as he is in
the house and speed him when he wants t'leave it. Wait, then, till I
can get your beautiful presents int'your chariot, and till you have
yourself seen them. I will tell the women t'prepare a sufficient
dinner for you of what there may be in the house; it will be at once
more proper and cheaper for you t'get your dinner before setting out
on such a long journey. If, moreover, you have a fancy for making a
tour in Hellas or in the Peloponnese, I will yoke my horses, and will
conduct you myself through all our principal cities. N'one will send
us away empty handed; every one will give us something—a bronze tripod,
a couple of mules, or a gold cup."
"Menelaus," replied Telemachus, "I want t'g'home at once, for when I
came away I left my property without protection, and fear that while
looking for my father I shall come t'ruin myself, or find that
something valuable has been stolen during my absence."

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the interactions between Telemachus and Menelaus.
characters.quote: Moderation is best in all things, and not letting a man g'when he wants t'd's'is as bad as telling him t'g'if he would like t'stay.

characters.name: Urgency To Return
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus' desire to return home drives the scene's action.
characters.quote: I want t'g'home at once, for when I came away I left my property without protection.

scenes.title: Menelaus's Farewell
scenes.summary: Menelaus bids farewell to Telemachus and Pisistratus.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the chariot.
scenes.text:
When Menelaus heard this he immediately told his wife and servants to
prepare a sufficient dinner from what there might be in the house. At
this moment Eteoneus joined him, for he lived close by and had just got
up; s'Menelaus told him t'light the fire and cook some meat, which he
at once did. Then Menelaus went down int'his fragrant store room,130
not alone, but Helen went too, with Megapenthes. When he reached the
place where the treasures of his house were kept, he selected a double
cup, and told his son Megapenthes t'bring als'a silver mixing bowl.
Meanwhile Helen went t'the chest where she kept the lovely dresses
which she had made with her own hands, and took out one that was
largest and most beautifully enriched with embroidery; it glittered
like a star, and lay at the very bottom of the chest. 131 Then they all
came back through the house again till they got t'Telemachus, and
Menelaus said, "Telemachus, may Jove, the mighty husband of Juno, bring
you safely home according t'your desire. I will now present you with
the finest and most precious piece of plate in all my house. It is a
mixing bowl of pure silver, except the rim, which is inlaid with gold,
and it is the work of Vulcan. Phaedimus king of the Sidonians made me a
present of it in the course of a visit that I paid him while I was on
my return home. I should like t'give it t'you."
With these words he placed the double cup in the hands of Telemachus,
while Megapenthes brought the beautiful mixing bowl and set it before
him. Hard by stood lovely Helen with the robe ready in her hand.
"I too, my son," said she, "have something for you as a keepsake from
the hand of Helen; it is for your bride t'wear upon her wedding day.
Till then, get your dear mother t'keep it for you; thus may you go
back rejoicing t'your own country and t'your home."
S'saying she gave the robe over t'him and he received it gladly. Then
Pisistratus put the presents int'the chariot, and admired them all as
he did so. Presently Menelaus took Telemachus and Pisistratus int'the
house, and they both of them sat down t'table. A maid servant brought
them water in a beautiful golden ewer, and poured it int'a silver
basin for them t'wash their hands, and she drew a clean table beside
them; an upper servant brought them bread and offered them many good
things of what there was in the house. Eteoneus carved the meat and
gave them each their portions, while Megapenthes poured out the wine.
Then they laid their hands upon the good things that were before them,
but as soon as they had had enough t'eat and drink Telemachus and
Pisistratus yoked the horses, and took their places in the chariot.
They drove out through the inner gateway and under the echoing
gatehouse of the outer court, and Menelaus came after them with a
golden goblet of wine in his right hand that they might make a
drink-offering before they set out. He stood in front of the horses and
pledged them, saying, "Farewell t'both of you; see that you tell
Nestor how I have treated you, for he was as kind t'me as any father
could be while we Achaeans were fighting before Troy."

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Central to the scene as Menelaus hosts Telemachus.
characters.quote: I will now present you with the finest and most precious piece of plate in all my house.

characters.name: Gift-giving
characters.importance_exp: Significant as Menelaus and Helen give gifts to Telemachus.
characters.quote: it is for your bride t'wear upon her wedding day.

characters.name: Nostalgia
characters.importance_exp: Reflects on past relationships and kindness shared.
characters.quote: see that you tell Nestor how I have treated you, for he was as kind t'me as any father could be while we Achaeans were fighting before Troy.

scenes.title: The Omen
scenes.summary: Telemachus and Pisistratus witness an omen as they depart.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the road.
scenes.text:
"We will be sure, sir," answered Telemachus, "t'tell him everything as
soon as we see him. I wish I were as certain of finding Ulysses
returned when I get back t'Ithaca, that I might tell him of the very
great kindness you have shown me and of the many beautiful presents I
am taking with me."
As he was thus speaking a bird flew on his right hand—an eagle with a
great white goose in its talons which it had carried off from the farm
yard—and all the men and women were running after it and shouting. It
came quite close up t'them and flew away on their right hands in front
of the horses. When they saw it they were glad, and their hearts took
comfort within them, whereon Pisistratus said, "Tell me, Menelaus, has
heaven sent this omen for us or for you?"
Menelaus was thinking what would be the most proper answer for him to
make, but Helen was to'quick for him and said, "I will read this
matter as heaven has put it in my heart, and as I doubt not that it
will come t'pass. The eagle came from the mountain where it was bred
and has its nest, and in like manner Ulysses, after having travelled
far and suffered much, will return t'take his revenge—if indeed he is
not back already and hatching mischief for the suitors."

characters.name: Hope For Return
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the characters' motivations and actions.
characters.quote: I wish I were as certain of finding Ulysses returned when I get back t'Ithaca, that I might tell him of the very great kindness you have shown me.

characters.name: Dreams And Omens
characters.importance_exp: The omen signifies divine intervention and foreshadows future events.
characters.quote: I will read this matter as heaven has put it in my heart, and as I doubt not that it will come t'pass.

characters.name: Gratitude
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus expresses gratitude, highlighting relationships and support.
characters.quote: of the very great kindness you have shown me

scenes.title: Arrival at Pylos
scenes.summary: Telemachus arrives at Pylos and speaks with Pisistratus.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Pylos.
scenes.text:
"May Jove s'grant it," replied Telemachus, "if it should prove t'be
so, I will make vows t'you as though you were a god, even when I am at
home."
As he spoke he lashed his horses and they started off at full speed
through the town towards the open country. They swayed the yoke upon
their necks and travelled the whole day long till the sun set and
darkness was over all the land. Then they reached Pherae, where Diocles
lived wh'was son of Ortilochus, the son of Alpheus. There they passed
the night and were treated hospitably. When the child of morning,
rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, they again yoked their horses and their
places in the chariot. They drove out through the inner gateway and
under the echoing gatehouse of the outer court. Then Pisistratus lashed
his horses on and they flew forward nothing loath; ere long they came
t'Pylos, and then Telemachus said:
"Pisistratus, I hope you will promise t'd'what I am going t'ask you.
You know our fathers were old friends before us; moreover, we are both
of an age, and this journey has brought us together still more closely;
d'not, therefore, take me past my ship, but leave me there, for if I
g't'your father's house he will try t'keep me in the warmth of his
good will towards me, and I must g'home at once."
Pisistratus thought how he should d'as he was asked, and in the end he
deemed it best t'turn his horses towards the ship, and put Menelaus's
beautiful presents of gold and raiment in the stern of the vessel. Then
he said, "G'on board at once and tell your men t'd's'als'before I
can reach home t'tell my father. I know how obstinate he is, and am
sure he will not let you go; he will come down here t'fetch you, and
he will not g'back without you. But he will be very angry."
With this he drove his goodly steeds back t'the city of the Pylians

characters.name: Joyful Companionship
characters.importance_exp: The bond between Telemachus and Pisistratus is central to the scene.
characters.quote: You know our fathers were old friends before us; moreover, we are both of an age, and this journey has brought us together still more closely;

characters.name: Longing For Home
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus's desire to return home drives the narrative.
characters.quote: I must g'home at once.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: The treatment they receive reflects the theme of hospitality in their journey.
characters.quote: they passed the night and were treated hospitably.

scenes.title: Telemachus Meets Theoclymenus
scenes.summary: Telemachus meets Theoclymenus, a seer, and offers him passage.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the ship.
scenes.text:
and soon reached his home, but Telemachus called the men together and
gave his orders. "Now, my men," said he, "get everything in order on
board the ship, and let us set out home."
Thus did he speak, and they went on board even as he had said. But as
Telemachus was thus busied, praying als'and sacrificing t'Minerva in
the ship's stern, there came t'him a man from a distant country, a
seer, wh'was flying from Argos because he had killed a man. He was
descended from Melampus, wh'used t'live in Pylos, the land of sheep;
he was rich and owned a great house, but he was driven int'exile by
the great and powerful king Neleus. Neleus seized his goods and held
them for a whole year, during which he was a close prisoner in the
house of king Phylacus, and in much distress of mind both on account of
the daughter of Neleus and because he was haunted by a great sorrow
that dread Erinys had laid upon him. In the end, however, he escaped
with his life, drove the cattle from Phylace t'Pylos, avenged the
wrong that had been done him, and gave the daughter of Neleus t'his
brother. Then he left the country and went t'Argos, where it was
ordained that he should reign over much people. There he married,
established himself, and had tw'famous sons Antiphates and Mantius.
Antiphates became father of Oicleus, and Oicleus of Amphiaraus, wh'was
dearly loved both by Jove and by Apollo, but he did not live t'old
age, for he was killed in Thebes by reason of a woman's gifts. His sons
were Alcmaeon and Amphilochus. Mantius, the other son of Melampus, was
father t'Polypheides and Cleitus. Aurora, throned in gold, carried off
Cleitus for his beauty's sake, that he might dwell among the immortals,
but Apoll'made Polypheides the greatest seer in the whole world now
that Amphiaraus was dead. He quarrelled with his father and went to
live in Hyperesia, where he remained and prophesied for all men.
His son, Theoclymenus, it was wh'now came up t'Telemachus as he was
making drink-offerings and praying in his ship. "Friend," said he, "now
that I find you sacrificing in this place, I beseech you by your
sacrifices themselves, and by the god t'whom you make them, I pray you
als'by your own head and by those of your followers tell me the truth
and nothing but the truth. Wh'and whence are you? Tell me als'of your
town and parents."
Telemachus said, "I will answer you quite truly. I am from Ithaca, and
my father is Ulysses, as surely as that he ever lived. But he has come
t'some miserable end. Therefore I have taken this ship and got my crew
together t'see if I can hear any news of him, for he has been away a
long time."
"I too," answered Theoclymenus, "am an exile, for I have killed a man
of my own race. He has many brothers and kinsmen in Argos, and they
have great power among the Argives. I am flying t'escape death at
their hands, and am thus doomed t'be a wanderer on the face of the
earth. I am your suppliant; take me, therefore, on board your ship that
they may not kill me, for I know they are in pursuit."
"I will not refuse you," replied Telemachus, "if you wish t'join us.
Come, therefore, and in Ithaca we will treat you hospitably according
t'what we have."

characters.name: Exile And Wandering
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the characters' motivations and backgrounds.
characters.quote: I am your suppliant; take me, therefore, on board your ship that they may not kill me, for I know they are in pursuit.

characters.name: Search For Identity
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus' quest for news of his father drives the narrative.
characters.quote: I am from Ithaca, and my father is Ulysses, as surely as that he ever lived.

characters.name: Hospitality And Suppliancy
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus' willingness to help Theoclymenus reflects cultural values.
characters.quote: I will not refuse you, replied Telemachus, if you wish t'join us.

scenes.title: Setting Sail
scenes.summary: Telemachus and his crew set sail from Pylos.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the sea.
scenes.text:
On this he received Theoclymenus' spear and laid it down on the deck of
the ship. He went on board and sat in the stern, bidding Theoclymenus
sit beside him; then the men let g'the hawsers. Telemachus told them
t'catch hold of the ropes, and they made all haste t'd'so. They set
the mast in its socket in the cross plank, raised it and made it fast
with the forestays, and they hoisted their white sails with sheets of
twisted ox hide. Minerva sent them a fair wind that blew fresh and
strong t'take the ship on her course as fast as possible. Thus then
they passed by Crouni and Chalcis.

characters.name: Journey And Struggle
characters.importance_exp: This scene marks the start of an important journey.
characters.quote: They set the mast in its socket in the cross plank, raised it and made it fast with the forestays, and they hoisted their white sails with sheets of twisted ox hide.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The influence of the gods is crucial in this scene.
characters.quote: Minerva sent them a fair wind that blew fresh and strong t'take the ship on her course as fast as possible.

scenes.title: Ulysses and Eumaeus
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Eumaeus discuss plans in the hut.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Ulysses's hut.
scenes.text:
Presently the sun set and darkness was over all the land. The vessel
made a quick passage t'Pheae and thence on t'Elis, where the Epeans
rule. Telemachus then headed her for the flying islands,132 wondering
within himself whether he should escape death or should be taken
prisoner.
Meanwhile Ulysses and the swineherd were eating their supper in the
hut, and the men supped with them. As soon as they had had t'eat and
drink, Ulysses began trying t'prove the swineherd and see whether he
would continue t'treat him kindly, and ask him t'stay on at the
station or pack him off t'the city; s'he said:
"Eumaeus, and all of you, to-morrow I want t'g'away and begin begging
about the town, s'as t'be n'more trouble t'you or t'your men. Give
me your advice therefore, and let me have a good guide t'g'with me
and show me the way. I will g'the round of the city begging as I needs
must, t'see if any one will give me a drink and a piece of bread. I
should like als't'g't'the house of Ulysses and bring news of her
husband t'Queen Penelope. I could then g'about among the suitors and
see if out of all their abundance they will give me a dinner. I should
soon make them an excellent servant in all sorts of ways. Listen and
believe when I tell you that by the blessing of Mercury wh'gives grace
and good name t'the works of all men, there is n'one living wh'would
make a more handy servant than I should—t'put fresh wood on the fire,
chop fuel, carve, cook, pour out wine, and d'all those services that
poor men have t'd'for their betters."
The swineherd was very much disturbed when he heard this. "Heaven help
me," he exclaimed, "what ever can have put such a notion as that into
your head? If you g'near the suitors you will be undone t'a
certainty, for their pride and insolence reach the very heavens. They
would never think of taking a man like you for a servant. Their
servants are all young men, well dressed, wearing good cloaks and
shirts, with well looking faces and their hair always tidy, the tables
are kept quite clean and are loaded with bread, meat, and wine. Stay
where you are, then; you are not in anybody's way; I d'not mind your
being here, n'more d'any of the others, and when Telemachus comes
home he will give you a shirt and cloak and will send you wherever you
want t'go."
Ulysses answered, "I hope you may be as dear t'the gods as you are to
me, for having saved me from going about and getting int'trouble;
there is nothing worse than being always on the tramp; still, when men
have once got low down in the world they will g'through a great deal
on behalf of their miserable bellies. Since, however, you press me to
stay here and await the return of Telemachus, tell me about Ulysses'
mother, and his father whom he left on the threshold of old age when he
set out for Troy. Are they still living or are they already dead and in
the house of Hades?"
"I will tell you all about them," replied Eumaeus, "Laertes is still
living and prays heaven t'let him depart peacefully in his own house,
for he is terribly distressed about the absence of his son, and also
about the death of his wife, which grieved him greatly and aged him
more than anything else did. She came t'an unhappy end133 through
sorrow for her son: may n'friend or neighbour wh'has dealt kindly by
me come t'such an end as she did. As long as she was still living,
though she was always grieving, I used t'like seeing her and asking
her how she did, for she brought me up along with her daughter Ctimene,
the youngest of her children; we were boy and girl together, and she
made little difference between us. When, however, we both grew up, they
sent Ctimene t'Same and received a splendid dowry for her. As for me,
my mistress gave me a good shirt and cloak with a pair of sandals for
my feet, and sent me off int'the country, but she was just as fond of
me as ever. This is all over now. Still it has pleased heaven to
prosper my work in the situation which I now hold. I have enough t'eat
and drink, and can find something for any respectable stranger who
comes here; but there is n'getting a kind word or deed out of my
mistress, for the house has fallen int'the hands of wicked people.
Servants want sometimes t'see their mistress and have a talk with her;
they like t'have something t'eat and drink at the house, and
something to't'take back with them int'the country. This is what
will keep servants in a good humour."
Ulysses answered, "Then you must have been a very little fellow,
Eumaeus, when you were taken s'far away from your home and parents.
Tell me, and tell me true, was the city in which your father and mother
lived sacked and pillaged, or did some enemies carry you off when you
were alone tending sheep or cattle, ship you off here, and sell you for
whatever your master gave them?"
"Stranger," replied Eumaeus, "as regards your question: sit still, make
yourself comfortable, drink your wine, and listen t'me. The nights are
now at their longest; there is plenty of time both for sleeping and
sitting up talking together; you ought not t'g't'bed till bed time,
to'much sleep is as bad as to'little; if any one of the others wishes
t'g't'bed let him leave us and d'so; he can then take my master's
pigs out when he has done breakfast in the morning. We to'will sit
here eating and drinking in the hut, and telling one another stories

characters.name: Struggle For Survival
characters.importance_exp: Survival is a central concern for Ulysses and Eumaeus.
characters.quote: I will g'the round of the city begging as I needs must, t'see if any one will give me a drink and a piece of bread.

characters.name: Loyalty And Care
characters.importance_exp: The bond between Ulysses and Eumaeus highlights loyalty.
characters.quote: I hope you may be as dear t'the gods as you are to me, for having saved me from going about and getting int'trouble;

characters.name: Loss And Absence
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus reflects on the loss of his mistress and the impact of grief.
characters.quote: Laertes is still living and prays heaven t'let him depart peacefully in his own house, for he is terribly distressed about the absence of his son.

characters.name: Social Class And Status
characters.importance_exp: The contrast between Ulysses and the suitors emphasizes social hierarchy.
characters.quote: If you g'near the suitors you will be undone t'a certainty, for their pride and insolence reach the very heavens.

scenes.title: Telemachus Returns to Ithaca
scenes.summary: Telemachus returns to Ithaca and plans to visit the herdsmen.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Ithaca.
scenes.text:
about our misfortunes; for when a man has suffered much, and been
buffeted about in the world, he takes pleasure in recalling the memory
of sorrows that have long gone by. As regards your question, then, my
tale is as follows:
"You may have heard of an island called Syra that lies over above
Ortygia,134 where the land begins t'turn round and look in another
direction.135 It is not very thickly peopled, but the soil is good,
with much pasture fit for cattle and sheep, and it abounds with wine
and wheat. Dearth never comes there, nor are the people plagued by any
sickness, but when they grow old Apoll'comes with Diana and kills them
with his painless shafts. It contains tw'communities, and the whole
country is divided between these two. My father Ctesius son of Ormenus,
a man comparable t'the gods, reigned over both.
"Now t'this place there came some cunning traders from Phoenicia (for
the Phoenicians are great mariners) in a ship which they had freighted
with gewgaws of all kinds. There happened t'be a Phoenician woman in
my father's house, very tall and comely, and an excellent servant;
these scoundrels got hold of her one day when she was washing near
their ship, seduced her, and cajoled her in ways that n'woman can
resist, n'matter how good she may be by nature. The man wh'had
seduced her asked her wh'she was and where she came from, and on this
she told him her father's name. 'I come from Sidon,' said she, 'and am
daughter t'Arybas, a man rolling in wealth. One day as I was coming
int'the town from the country, some Taphian pirates seized me and took
me here over the sea, where they sold me t'the man wh'owns this
house, and he gave them their price for me.'
"The man wh'had seduced her then said, 'Would you like t'come along
with us t'see the house of your parents and your parents themselves?
They are both alive and are said t'be well off.'
"'I will d's'gladly,' answered she, 'if you men will first swear me a
solemn oath that you will d'me n'harm by the way.'
"They all swore as she told them, and when they had completed their
oath the woman said, 'Hush; and if any of your men meets me in the
street or at the well, d'not let him speak t'me, for fear some one
should g'and tell my master, in which case he would suspect something.
He would put me in prison, and would have all of you murdered; keep
your own counsel therefore; buy your merchandise as fast as you can,
and send me word when you have done loading. I will bring as much gold
as I can lay my hands on, and there is something else als'that I can
d'towards paying my fare. I am nurse t'the son of the good man of the
house, a funny little fellow just able t'run about. I will carry him
off in your ship, and you will get a great deal of money for him if you
take him and sell him in foreign parts.'
"On this she went back t'the house. The Phoenicians stayed a whole
year till they had loaded their ship with much precious merchandise,
and then, when they had got freight enough, they sent t'tell the
woman. Their messenger, a very cunning fellow, came t'my father's
house bringing a necklace of gold with amber beads strung among it; and
while my mother and the servants had it in their hands admiring it and
bargaining about it, he made a sign quietly t'the woman and then went
back t'the ship, whereon she took me by the hand and led me out of the
house. In the fore part of the house she saw the tables set with the
cups of guests wh'had been feasting with my father, as being in
attendance on him; these were now all gone t'a meeting of the public
assembly, s'she snatched up three cups and carried them off in the
bosom of her dress, while I followed her, for I knew n'better. The sun
was now set, and darkness was over all the land, s'we hurried on as
fast as we could till we reached the harbour, where the Phoenician ship
was lying. When they had got on board they sailed their ways over the
sea, taking us with them, and Jove sent then a fair wind; six days did
we sail both night and day, but on the seventh day Diana struck the
woman and she fell heavily down int'the ship's hold as though she were
a sea gull alighting on the water; s'they threw her overboard t'the
seals and fishes, and I was left all sorrowful and alone. Presently the
winds and waves took the ship t'Ithaca, where Laertes gave sundry of
his chattels for me, and thus it was that ever I came t'set eyes upon
this country."
Ulysses answered, "Eumaeus, I have heard the story of your misfortunes
with the most lively interest and pity, but Jove has given you good as
well as evil, for in spite of everything you have a good master, who
sees that you always have enough t'eat and drink; and you lead a good
life, whereas I am still going about begging my way from city t'city."
Thus did they converse, and they had only a very little time left for
sleep, for it was soon daybreak. In the mean time Telemachus and his
crew were nearing land, s'they loosed the sails, took down the mast,
and rowed the ship int'the harbour.136 They cast out their mooring
stones and made fast the hawsers; they then got out upon the sea shore,
mixed their wine, and got dinner ready. As soon as they had had enough
t'eat and drink Telemachus said, "Take the ship on t'the town, but
leave me here, for I want t'look after the herdsmen on one of my
farms. In the evening, when I have seen all I want, I will come down to
the city, and to-morrow morning in return for your trouble I will give
you all a good dinner with meat and wine." 137
Then Theoclymenus said, "And what, my dear young friend, is t'become
of me? T'whose house, among all your chief men, am I t'repair? or
shall I g'straight t'your own house and t'your mother?"
"At any other time," replied Telemachus, "I should have bidden you go
t'my own house, for you would find n'want of hospitality; at the
present moment, however, you would not be comfortable there, for I
shall be away, and my mother will not see you; she does not often show
herself even t'the suitors, but sits at her loom weaving in an upper
chamber, out of their way; but I can tell you a man whose house you can
g'to—I mean Eurymachus the son of Polybus, wh'is held in the highest
estimation by every one in Ithaca. He is much the best man and the most
persistent wooer, of all those wh'are paying court t'my mother and
trying t'take Ulysses' place. Jove, however, in heaven alone knows
whether or n'they will come t'a bad end before the marriage takes
place."
As he was speaking a bird flew by upon his right hand—a hawk, Apollo's
messenger. It held a dove in its talons, and the feathers, as it tore
them off,138 fell t'the ground midway between Telemachus and the ship.
On this Theoclymenus called him apart and caught him by the hand.
"Telemachus," said he, "that bird did not fly on your right hand
without having been sent there by some god. As soon as I saw it I knew
it was an omen; it means that you will remain powerful and that there
will be n'house in Ithaca more royal than your own."
"I wish it may prove so," answered Telemachus. "If it does, I will show
you s'much good will and give you s'many presents that all wh'meet
you will congratulate you."
Then he said t'his friend Piraeus, "Piraeus, son of Clytius, you have
throughout shown yourself the most willing t'serve me of all those who
have accompanied me t'Pylos; I wish you would take this stranger to
your own house and entertain him hospitably till I can come for him."
And Piraeus answered, "Telemachus, you may stay away as long as you
please, but I will look after him for you, and he shall find n'lack of
hospitality."
As he spoke he went on board, and bade the others d's'als'and loose
the hawsers, s'they took their places in the ship. But Telemachus
bound on his sandals, and took a long and doughty spear with a head of
sharpened bronze from the deck of the ship. Then they loosed the
hawsers, thrust the ship off from land, and made on towards the city as
they had been told t'do, while Telemachus strode on as fast as he
could, till he reached the homestead where his countless herds of swine
were feeding, and where dwelt the excellent swineherd, wh'was so
devoted a servant t'his master.
