characters.importance_exp: The theme of fate is central as Penelope's actions are influenced by divine intervention.
characters.quote: Minerva now put it in Penelope's mind t'make the suitors try their skill with the bow and with the iron axes, in contest among themselves, as a means of bringing about their destruction.

characters.name: Loss And Absence
characters.importance_exp: Penelope's emotional state reflects her deep sense of loss and longing for Ulysses.
characters.quote: she sat down with it on her knees, weeping bitterly as she took the bow out of its case

characters.name: Love And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: The suitors' abuse of hospitality highlights themes of betrayal and disrespect.
characters.quote: you suitors, wh'persist in abusing the hospitality of this house because its owner has been long absent

scenes.title: The Contest Begins
scenes.summary: Telemachus proposes the contest for the bow.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the cloister where the suitors are.
scenes.text:
bidden him. Hard by, the stockman wept als'when he saw his master's
bow, but Antinous scolded them. "You country louts," said he, "silly
simpletons; why should you add t'the sorrows of your mistress by
crying in this way? She has enough t'grieve her in the loss of her
husband; sit still, therefore, and eat your dinners in silence, or go
outside if you want t'cry, and leave the bow behind you. We suitors
shall have t'contend for it with might and main, for we shall find it
n'light matter t'string such a bow as this is. There is not a man of
us all wh'is such another as Ulysses; for I have seen him and remember
him, though I was then only a child."
This was what he said, but all the time he was expecting t'be able to
string the bow and shoot through the iron, whereas in fact he was t'be
the first that should taste of the arrows from the hands of Ulysses,
whom he was dishonouring in his own house—egging the others on t'd'so
also.
Then Telemachus spoke. "Great heavens!" he exclaimed, "Jove must have
robbed me of my senses. Here is my dear and excellent mother saying she
will quit this house and marry again, yet I am laughing and enjoying
myself as though there were nothing happening. But, suitors, as the
contest has been agreed upon, let it g'forward. It is for a woman
whose peer is not t'be found in Pylos, Argos, or Mycene, nor yet in
Ithaca nor on the mainland. You know this as well as I do; what need
have I t'speak in praise of my mother? Come on, then, make n'excuses
for delay, but let us see whether you can string the bow or no. I too
will make trial of it, for if I can string it and shoot through the
iron, I shall not suffer my mother t'quit this house with a stranger,
not if I can win the prizes which my father won before me."
As he spoke he sprang from his seat, threw his crimson cloak from him,
and took his sword from his shoulder. First he set the axes in a row,
in a long groove which he had dug for them, and had made straight by
line.162 Then he stamped the earth tight round them, and everyone was
surprised when they saw him set them up s'orderly, though he had never
seen anything of the kind before. This done, he went on t'the pavement
t'make trial of the bow; thrice did he tug at it, trying with all his
might t'draw the string, and thrice he had t'leave off, though he had
hoped t'string the bow and shoot through the iron. He was trying for
the fourth time, and would have strung it had not Ulysses made a sign
t'check him in spite of all his eagerness. S'he said:
"Alas! I shall either be always feeble and of n'prowess, or I am too
young, and have not yet reached my full strength s'as t'be able to
hold my own if any one attacks me. You others, therefore, wh'are
stronger than I, make trial of the bow and get this contest settled."
On this he put the bow down, letting it lean against the door [that led
int'the house] with the arrow standing against the top of the bow.

characters.name: Conflict With Suitors
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the contest for the bow.
characters.quote: Come on, then, make n'excuses for delay, but let us see whether you can string the bow or no.

characters.name: Loss And Absence
characters.importance_exp: The emotional weight of loss is felt by the characters.
characters.quote: She has enough t'grieve her in the loss of her husband;

characters.name: Search For Identity
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus grapples with his father's legacy and his own identity.
characters.quote: I shall not suffer my mother t'quit this house with a stranger, not if I can win the prizes which my father won before me.

scenes.title: The Suitors' Trials
scenes.summary: The suitors attempt to string the bow but fail.
scenes.explanation: Location remains in the cloister as the contest continues.
scenes.text:
Then he sat down on the seat from which he had risen, and Antinous
said:
"Come on each of you in his turn, going towards the right from the
place at which the cupbearer begins when he is handing round the wine."
The rest agreed, and Leiodes son of Oenops was the first t'rise. He
was sacrificial priest t'the suitors, and sat in the corner near the
mixing-bowl. 163 He was the only man wh'hated their evil deeds and was
indignant with the others. He was now the first t'take the bow and
arrow, s'he went on t'the pavement t'make his trial, but he could
not string the bow, for his hands were weak and unused t'hard work,
they therefore soon grew tired, and he said t'the suitors, "My
friends, I cannot string it; let another have it, this bow shall take
the life and soul out of many a chief among us, for it is better t'die
than t'live after having missed the prize that we have s'long striven
for, and which has brought us s'long together. Some one of us is even
now hoping and praying that he may marry Penelope, but when he has seen
this bow and tried it, let him wo'and make bridal offerings t'some
other woman, and let Penelope marry whoever makes her the best offer
and whose lot it is t'win her."
On this he put the bow down, letting it lean against the door,164 with
the arrow standing against the tip of the bow. Then he took his seat
again on the seat from which he had risen; and Antinous rebuked him
saying:
"Leiodes, what are you talking about? Your words are monstrous and
intolerable; it makes me angry t'listen t'you. Shall, then, this bow
take the life of many a chief among us, merely because you cannot bend
it yourself? True, you were not born t'be an archer, but there are
others wh'will soon string it."
Then he said t'Melanthius the goatherd, "Look sharp, light a fire in
the court, and set a seat hard by with a sheep skin on it; bring us
als'a large ball of lard, from what they have in the house. Let us
warm the bow and grease it—we will then make trial of it again, and
bring the contest t'an end."

characters.name: Desperation For Help
characters.importance_exp: This theme drives the actions of the suitors as they compete for Penelope.
characters.quote: this bow shall take the life and soul out of many a chief among us, for it is better t'die than t'live after having missed the prize that we have s'long striven for, and which has brought us s'long together.

characters.name: Rejection And Failure
characters.importance_exp: The inability to string the bow symbolizes the suitors' impending failure.
characters.quote: I cannot string it; let another have it, this bow shall take the life and soul out of many a chief among us.

characters.name: War And Conflict
characters.importance_exp: The tension between Leiodes and Antinous highlights the discord among the suitors.
characters.quote: Your words are monstrous and intolerable; it makes me angry t'listen t'you.

scenes.title: Ulysses Reveals Himself
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks to Eumaeus and Philoetius about his return.
scenes.explanation: Location changes outside the house.
scenes.text:
Melanthius lit the fire, and set a seat covered with sheep skins beside
it. He als'brought a great ball of lard from what they had in the
house, and the suitors warmed the bow and again made trial of it, but
they were none of them nearly strong enough t'string it. Nevertheless
there still remained Antinous and Eurymachus, wh'were the ringleaders
among the suitors and much the foremost among them all.
Then the swineherd and the stockman left the cloisters together, and
Ulysses followed them. When they had got outside the gates and the
outer yard, Ulysses said t'them quietly:
"Stockman, and you swineherd, I have something in my mind which I am in
doubt whether t'say or no; but I think I will say it. What manner of
men would you be t'stand by Ulysses, if some god should bring him back
here all of a sudden? Say which you are disposed t'do—t'side with the
suitors, or with Ulysses?"
"Father Jove," answered the stockman, "would indeed that you might so
ordain it. If some god were but t'bring Ulysses back, you should see
with what might and main I would fight for him."
In like words Eumaeus prayed t'all the gods that Ulysses might return;
when, therefore, he saw for certain what mind they were of, Ulysses
said, "It is I, Ulysses, wh'am here. I have suffered much, but at
last, in the twentieth year, I am come back t'my own country. I find
that you tw'alone of all my servants are glad that I should d'so, for
I have not heard any of the others praying for my return. T'you two,
therefore, will I unfold the truth as it shall be. If heaven shall
deliver the suitors int'my hands, I will find wives for both of you,
will give you house and holding close t'my own, and you shall be t'me
as though you were brothers and friends of Telemachus. I will now give
you convincing proofs that you may know me and be assured. See, here is
the scar from the boar's tooth that ripped me when I was out hunting on
Mt. Parnassus with the sons of Autolycus."
As he spoke he drew his rags aside from the great scar, and when they
had examined it thoroughly, they both of them wept about Ulysses, threw
their arms round him, and kissed his head and shoulders, while Ulysses
kissed their hands and faces in return. The sun would have gone down
upon their mourning if Ulysses had not checked them and said:
"Cease your weeping, lest some one should come outside and see us, and
tell those wh'are within. When you g'in, d's'separately, not both
together; I will g'first, and d'you follow afterwards; let this
moreover be the token between us; the suitors will all of them try to
prevent me from getting hold of the bow and quiver; d'you, therefore,
Eumaeus, place it in my hands when you are carrying it about, and tell
the women t'close the doors of their apartment. If they hear any
groaning or uproar as of men fighting about the house, they must not
come out; they must keep quiet, and stay where they are at their work.
And I charge you, Philoetius, t'make fast the doors of the outer
court, and t'bind them securely at once."

characters.name: Loyalty And Care
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central as it highlights the loyalty of Ulysses' servants.
characters.quote: If some god were but t'bring Ulysses back, you should see with what might and main I would fight for him.

characters.name: Identity And Recognition
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses reveals his identity to his loyal servants, which is crucial for the plot.
characters.quote: It is I, Ulysses, wh'am here. I have suffered much, but at last, in the twentieth year, I am come back t'my own country.

characters.name: Apology And Reconciliation
characters.importance_exp: The theme of hope is significant as Ulysses' return brings hope for redemption.
characters.quote: I will find wives for both of you, will give you house and holding close t'my own.

scenes.title: The Bow is Presented
scenes.summary: Telemachus insists on bringing the bow to Ulysses.
scenes.explanation: Location returns to inside the house.
scenes.text:
When he had thus spoken, he went back t'the house and took the seat
that he had left. Presently, his tw'servants followed him inside.
At this moment the bow was in the hands of Eurymachus, wh'was warming
it by the fire, but even s'he could not string it, and he was greatly
grieved. He heaved a deep sigh and said, "I grieve for myself and for
us all; I grieve that I shall have t'forg'the marriage, but I d'not
care nearly s'much about this, for there are plenty of other women in
Ithaca and elsewhere; what I feel most is the fact of our being so
inferior t'Ulysses in strength that we cannot string his bow. This
will disgrace us in the eyes of those wh'are yet unborn."
"It shall not be so, Eurymachus," said Antinous, "and you know it
yourself. Today is the feast of Apoll'throughout all the land; wh'can
string a bow on such a day as this? Put it on one side—as for the axes
they can stay where they are, for n'one is likely t'come t'the house
and take them away: let the cupbearer g'round with his cups, that we
may make our drink-offerings and drop this matter of the bow; we will
tell Melanthius t'bring us in some goats tomorrow—the best he has; we
can then offer thigh bones t'Apoll'the mighty archer, and again make
trial of the bow, s'as t'bring the contest t'an end."
The rest approved his words, and thereon men servants poured water over
the hands of the guests, while pages filled the mixing-bowls with wine
and water and handed it round after giving every man his
drink-offering. Then, when they had made their offerings and had drunk
each as much as he desired, Ulysses craftily said:—
"Suitors of the illustrious queen, listen that I may speak even as I am
minded. I appeal more especially t'Eurymachus, and t'Antinous wh'has
just spoken with s'much reason. Cease shooting for the present and
leave the matter t'the gods, but in the morning let heaven give
victory t'whom it will. For the moment, however, give me the bow that
I may prove the power of my hands among you all, and see whether I
still have as much strength as I used t'have, or whether travel and
neglect have made an end of it."
This made them all very angry, for they feared he might string the bow,
Antinous therefore rebuked him fiercely saying, "Wretched creature, you
have not s'much as a grain of sense in your whole body; you ought to
think yourself lucky in being allowed t'dine unharmed among your
betters, without having any smaller portion served you than we others
have had, and in being allowed t'hear our conversation. N'other
beggar or stranger has been allowed t'hear what we say among
ourselves; the wine must have been doing you a mischief, as it does
with all those wh'drink immoderately. It was wine that inflamed the
Centaur Eurytion when he was staying with Peirithous among the
Lapithae. When the wine had got int'his head, he went mad and did ill
deeds about the house of Peirithous; this angered the heroes wh'were
there assembled, s'they rushed at him and cut off his ears and
nostrils; then they dragged him through the doorway out of the house,
s'he went away crazed, and bore the burden of his crime, bereft of
understanding. Henceforth, therefore, there was war between mankind and
the centaurs, but he brought it upon himself through his own
drunkenness. In like manner I can tell you that it will g'hardly with
you if you string the bow: you will find n'mercy from any one here,
for we shall at once ship you off t'king Echetus, wh'kills every one
that comes near him: you will never get away alive, s'drink and keep
quiet without getting int'a quarrel with men younger than yourself."
Penelope then spoke t'him. "Antinous," said she, "it is not right that
you should ill-treat any guest of Telemachus wh'comes t'this house.
If the stranger should prove strong enough t'string the mighty bow of
Ulysses, can you suppose that he would take me home with him and make
me his wife? Even the man himself can have n'such idea in his mind:
none of you need let that disturb his feasting; it would be out of all
reason."
"Queen Penelope," answered Eurymachus, "we d'not suppose that this man
will take you away with him; it is impossible; but we are afraid lest
some of the baser sort, men or women among the Achaeans, should go
gossiping about and say, 'These suitors are a feeble folk; they are
paying court t'the wife of a brave man whose bow not one of them was
able t'string, and yet a beggarly tramp wh'came t'the house strung
it at once and sent an arrow through the iron.' This is what will be
said, and it will be a scandal against us."
"Eurymachus," Penelope answered, "people wh'persist in eating up the
estate of a great chieftain and dishonouring his house must not expect
others t'think well of them. Why then should you mind if men talk as
you think they will? This stranger is strong and well-built, he says
moreover that he is of noble birth. Give him the bow, and let us see
whether he can string it or no. I say—and it shall surely be—that if
Apoll'vouchsafes him the glory of stringing it, I will give him a
cloak and shirt of good wear, with a javelin t'keep off dogs and
robbers, and a sharp sword. I will als'give him sandals, and will see
him sent safely wherever he wants t'go."
Then Telemachus said, "Mother, I am the only man either in Ithaca or in
the islands that are over against Elis wh'has the right t'let any one
have the bow or t'refuse it. N'one shall force me one way or the
other, not even though I choose t'make the stranger a present of the
bow outright, and let him take it away with him. Go, then, within the
house and busy yourself with your daily duties, your loom, your
distaff, and the ordering of your servants. This bow is a man's matter,
and mine above all others, for it is I wh'am master here."
She went wondering back int'the house, and laid her son's saying in
her heart. Then going upstairs with her handmaids int'her room, she
mourned her dear husband till Minerva sent sweet sleep over her
eyelids.
The swineherd now took up the bow and was for taking it t'Ulysses, but
the suitors clamoured at him from all parts of the cloisters, and one
of them said, "You idiot, where are you taking the bow to? Are you out
of your wits? If Apoll'and the other gods will grant our prayer, your
own boarhounds shall get you int'some quiet little place, and worry
you t'death."
Eumaeus was frightened at the outcry they all raised, s'he put the bow
down then and there, but Telemachus shouted out at him from the other
side of the cloisters, and threatened him saying, "Father Eumaeus,
bring the bow on in spite of them, or young as I am I will pelt you
with stones back t'the country, for I am the better man of the two. I
wish I was as much stronger than all the other suitors in the house as
I am than you, I would soon send some of them off sick and sorry, for
they mean mischief."
Thus did he speak, and they all of them laughed heartily, which put
them in a better humour with Telemachus; s'Eumaeus brought the bow on
and placed it in the hands of Ulysses. When he had done this, he called
Euryclea apart and said t'her, "Euryclea, Telemachus says you are to
close the doors of the women's apartments. If they hear any groaning or
uproar as of men fighting about the house, they are not t'come out,
but are t'keep quiet and stay where they are at their work."
Euryclea did as she was told and closed the doors of the women's
apartments.

characters.name: Protection And Empowerment
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the contest of the bow.
characters.quote: I grieve that I shall have t'forg'the marriage, but I d'not care nearly s'much about this, for there are plenty of other women in Ithaca and elsewhere; what I feel most is the fact of our being so inferior t'Ulysses in strength that we cannot string his bow. This will disgrace us in the eyes of those wh'are yet unborn.

characters.name: Courage And Honor
characters.importance_exp: The suitors are concerned about their image.
characters.quote: we are afraid lest some of the baser sort, men or women among the Achaeans, should go gossiping about and say, 'These suitors are a feeble folk; they are paying court t'the wife of a brave man whose bow not one of them was able t'string.'

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The characters invoke the gods for guidance and strength.
characters.quote: let heaven give victory t'whom it will.

characters.name: Feminine Influence
characters.importance_exp: Penelope asserts her role in the household and the contest.
characters.quote: If the stranger should prove strong enough t'string the mighty bow of Ulysses, can you suppose that he would take me home with him and make me his wife?

scenes.title: The Bow is Strung
scenes.summary: Ulysses strings the bow and reveals his strength.
scenes.explanation: Location remains inside the house as the climax occurs.
scenes.text:
Meanwhile Philoetius slipped quietly out and made fast the gates of the
outer court. There was a ship's cable of byblus fibre lying in the
gatehouse, s'he made the gates fast with it and then came in again,
resuming the seat that he had left, and keeping an eye on Ulysses, who
had now got the bow in his hands, and was turning it every way about,
and proving it all over t'see whether the worms had been eating into
its tw'horns during his absence. Then would one turn towards his
neighbour saying, "This is some tricky old bow-fancier; either he has
got one like it at home, or he wants t'make one, in such workmanlike
style does the old vagabond handle it."
Another said, "I hope he may be n'more successful in other things than
he is likely t'be in stringing this bow."
But Ulysses, when he had taken it up and examined it all over, strung
it as easily as a skilled bard strings a new peg of his lyre and makes
the twisted gut fast at both ends. Then he took it in his right hand to
prove the string, and it sang sweetly under his touch like the
twittering of a swallow. The suitors were dismayed, and turned colour
as they heard it; at that moment, moreover, Jove thundered loudly as a
sign, and the heart of Ulysses rejoiced as he heard the omen that the
son of scheming Saturn had sent him.
He took an arrow that was lying upon the table165—for those which the
Achaeans were s'shortly about t'taste were all inside the quiver—he
laid it on the centre-piece of the bow, and drew the notch of the arrow
and the string toward him, still seated on his seat. When he had taken
aim he let fly, and his arrow pierced every one of the handle-holes of
the axes from the first onwards till it had gone right through them,
and int'the outer courtyard. Then he said t'Telemachus:
"Your guest has not disgraced you, Telemachus. I did not miss what I
aimed at, and I was not long in stringing my bow. I am still strong,
and not as the suitors twit me with being. Now, however, it is time for
the Achaeans t'prepare supper while there is still daylight, and then
otherwise t'disport themselves with song and dance which are the
crowning ornaments of a banquet."

characters.name: Strength And Skill
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses demonstrates his unmatched ability with the bow.
characters.quote: I did not miss what I aimed at, and I was not long in stringing my bow.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The thunder from Jove signifies divine approval of Ulysses.
characters.quote: Jove thundered loudly as a sign, and the heart of Ulysses rejoiced as he heard the omen that the son of scheming Saturn had sent him.

characters.name: Despair Of Suitors
characters.importance_exp: The suitors' reaction highlights their fear and realization of Ulysses' strength.
characters.quote: The suitors were dismayed, and turned colour as they heard it;

scenes.title: The Killing of the Suitors
scenes.summary: Ulysses reveals himself and kills Antinous.
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
THE KILLING OF THE SUITORS—THE MAIDS WH'HAVE MISCONDUCTED THEMSELVES
ARE MADE T'CLEANSE THE CLOISTERS AND ARE THEN HANGED.
Then Ulysses tore off his rags, and sprang on t'the broad pavement
with his bow and his quiver full of arrows. He shed the arrows on to
the ground at his feet and said, "The mighty contest is at an end. I
will now see whether Apoll'will vouchsafe it t'me t'hit another mark
which n'man has yet hit."
On this he aimed a deadly arrow at Antinous, wh'was about t'take up a
two-handled gold cup t'drink his wine and already had it in his hands.
He had n'thought of death—wh'amongst all the revellers would think
that one man, however brave, would stand alone among s'many and kill
him? The arrow struck Antinous in the throat, and the point went clean
through his neck, s'that he fell over and the cup dropped from his
hand, while a thick stream of blood gushed from his nostrils. He kicked
the table from him and upset the things on it, s'that the bread and
roasted meats were all soiled as they fell over on t'the ground.166
The suitors were in an uproar when they saw that a man had been hit;
they sprang in dismay one and all of them from their seats and looked
everywhere towards the walls, but there was neither shield nor spear,
and they rebuked Ulysses very angrily. "Stranger," said they, "you
shall pay for shooting people in this way: you shall see n'other
contest; you are a doomed man; he whom you have slain was the foremost
youth in Ithaca, and the vultures shall devour you for having killed
him."

characters.name: Retribution
characters.importance_exp: Revenge is the driving force behind Ulysses' actions.
characters.quote: The mighty contest is at an end. I will now see whether Apoll'will vouchsafe it t'me t'hit another mark which n'man has yet hit.

characters.name: Vengeance
characters.importance_exp: The scene depicts a form of justice being served through Ulysses' actions.
characters.quote: Stranger, said they, you shall pay for shooting people in this way: you shall see n'other contest; you are a doomed man; he whom you have slain was the foremost youth in Ithaca, and the vultures shall devour you for having killed him.

characters.name: Disruption And Chaos
characters.importance_exp: The aftermath of the shooting creates chaos among the suitors.
characters.quote: The suitors were in an uproar when they saw that a man had been hit; they sprang in dismay one and all of them from their seats and looked everywhere towards the walls, but there was neither shield nor spear.

scenes.title: The Uproar of the Suitors
scenes.summary: The suitors react in fear and attempt to negotiate.
scenes.explanation: Location remains the same, but tension escalates.
scenes.text:
Thus they spoke, for they thought that he had killed Antinous by
mistake, and did not perceive that death was hanging over the head of
every one of them. But Ulysses glared at them and said:
"Dogs, did you think that I should not come back from Troy? You have
wasted my substance,167 have forced my women servants t'lie with you,
and have wooed my wife while I was still living. You have feared
neither God nor man, and now you shall die."
They turned pale with fear as he spoke, and every man looked round
about t'see whither he might fly for safety, but Eurymachus alone
spoke.
"If you are Ulysses," said he, "then what you have said is just. We
have done much wrong on your lands and in your house. But Antinous who
was the head and front of the offending lies low already. It was all
his doing. It was not that he wanted t'marry Penelope; he did not so
much care about that; what he wanted was something quite different, and
Jove has not vouchsafed it t'him; he wanted t'kill your son and t'be
chief man in Ithaca. Now, therefore, that he has met the death which
was his due, spare the lives of your people. We will make everything
good among ourselves, and pay you in full for all that we have eaten
and drunk. Each one of us shall pay you a fine worth twenty oxen, and
we will keep on giving you gold and bronze till your heart is softened.
Until we have done this n'one can complain of your being enraged
against us."
Ulysses again glared at him and said, "Though you should give me all
that you have in the world both now and all that you ever shall have, I
will not stay my hand till I have paid all of you in full. You must
fight, or fly for your lives; and fly, not a man of you shall."

characters.name: Retribution
characters.importance_exp: Revenge drives Ulysses' actions in this scene.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The fury expressed in the character's words reveals a strong desire for justice and the consequences of betrayal.

characters.name: Fear And Horror
characters.importance_exp: Fear is palpable among the suitors as Ulysses confronts them.
characters.quote: They turned pale with fear as he spoke, and every man looked round about t'see whither he might fly for safety.

characters.name: Vengeance
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses seeks justice for the wrongs done to him.
characters.quote: Though you should give me all that you have in the world both now and all that you ever shall have, I will not stay my hand till I have paid all of you in full.

scenes.title: The Fight Begins
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Telemachus begin fighting the suitors.
scenes.explanation: The fight starts, changing the atmosphere.
scenes.text:
Their hearts sank as they heard him, but Eurymachus again spoke saying:
"My friends, this man will give us n'quarter. He will stand where he
is and shoot us down till he has killed every man among us. Let us then
show fight; draw your swords, and hold up the tables t'shield you from
his arrows. Let us have at him with a rush, t'drive him from the
pavement and doorway: we can then get through int'the town, and raise
such an alarm as shall soon stay his shooting."
As he spoke he drew his keen blade of bronze, sharpened on both sides,
and with a loud cry sprang towards Ulysses, but Ulysses instantly shot
an arrow int'his breast that caught him by the nipple and fixed itself
in his liver. He dropped his sword and fell doubled up over his table.
The cup and all the meats went over on t'the ground as he smote the
earth with his forehead in the agonies of death, and he kicked the
stool with his feet until his eyes were closed in darkness.
Then Amphinomus drew his sword and made straight at Ulysses t'try and
get him away from the door; but Telemachus was to'quick for him, and
struck him from behind; the spear caught him between the shoulders and
went right through his chest, s'that he fell heavily t'the ground and
struck the earth with his forehead. Then Telemachus sprang away from
him, leaving his spear still in the body, for he feared that if he
stayed t'draw it out, some one of the Achaeans might come up and hack
at him with his sword, or knock him down, s'he set off at a run, and
immediately was at his father's side. Then he said:
"Father, let me bring you a shield, tw'spears, and a brass helmet for
your temples. I will arm myself as well, and will bring other armour
for the swineherd and the stockman, for we had better be armed."
"Run and fetch them," answered Ulysses, "while my arrows hold out, or
when I am alone they may get me away from the door."
Telemachus did as his father said, and went off t'the store room where

characters.name: Desperation For Help
characters.importance_exp: The characters are in a dire situation, fighting for their lives.
characters.quote: Their hearts sank as they heard him, but Eurymachus again spoke saying: "My friends, this man will give us n'quarter."

characters.name: Independence
characters.importance_exp: The characters show bravery in the face of danger.
characters.quote: Let us then show fight; draw your swords, and hold up the tables t'shield you from his arrows.

characters.name: Violence And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: The scene is marked by intense violence and death.
characters.quote: He dropped his sword and fell doubled up over his table.

characters.name: Loyalty And Care
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus shows loyalty to his father by assisting him.
characters.quote: Then Telemachus sprang away from him, leaving his spear still in the body, for he feared that if he stayed t'draw it out...

scenes.title: The Arrival of Melanthius
scenes.summary: Melanthius brings arms to the suitors.
scenes.explanation: New location as Melanthius moves to the store room.
scenes.text:
the armour was kept. He chose four shields, eight spears, and four
brass helmets with horse-hair plumes. He brought them with all speed to
his father, and armed himself first, while the stockman and the
swineherd als'put on their armour, and took their places near Ulysses.
Meanwhile Ulysses, as long as his arrows lasted, had been shooting the
suitors one by one, and they fell thick on one another: when his arrows
gave out, he set the bow t'stand against the end wall of the house by
the door post, and hung a shield four hides thick about his shoulders;
on his comely head he set his helmet, well wrought with a crest of
horse-hair that nodded menacingly above it,168 and he grasped two
redoubtable bronze-shod spears.
Now there was a trap door169 on the wall, while at one end of the
pavement170 there was an exit leading t'a narrow passage, and this
exit was closed by a well-made door. Ulysses told Philoetius t'stand
by this door and guard it, for only one person could attack it at a
time. But Agelaus shouted out, "Cannot some one g'up t'the trap door
and tell the people what is going on? Help would come at once, and we
should soon make an end of this man and his shooting."
"This may not be, Agelaus," answered Melanthius, "the mouth of the
narrow passage is dangerously near the entrance t'the outer court. One
brave man could prevent any number from getting in. But I know what I
will do, I will bring you arms from the store-room, for I am sure it is
there that Ulysses and his son have put them."
On this the goatherd Melanthius went by back passages t'the store-room
of Ulysses' house. There he chose twelve shields, with as many helmets
and spears, and brought them back as fast as he could t'give them to
the suitors. Ulysses' heart began t'fail him when he saw the
suitors171 putting on their armour and brandishing their spears. He saw
the greatness of the danger, and said t'Telemachus, "Some one of the
women inside is helping the suitors against us, or it may be
Melanthius."
Telemachus answered, "The fault, father, is mine, and mine only; I left
the store room door open, and they have kept a sharper look out than I
have. Go, Eumaeus, put the door to, and see whether it is one of the
women wh'is doing this, or whether, as I suspect, it is Melanthius the

characters.name: Love And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: Betrayal is crucial as it reveals internal treachery.

scenes.title: Capturing Melanthius
scenes.summary: Ulysses' men capture Melanthius.
scenes.explanation: The scene shifts to the capture of Melanthius.
scenes.text:
son of Dolius."
Thus did they converse. Meanwhile Melanthius was again going t'the
store room t'fetch more armour, but the swineherd saw him and said to
Ulysses wh'was beside him, "Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, it is that
scoundrel Melanthius, just as we suspected, wh'is going t'the store
room. Say, shall I kill him, if I can get the better of him, or shall I
bring him here that you may take your own revenge for all the many
wrongs that he has done in your house?"
Ulysses answered, "Telemachus and I will hold these suitors in check,
n'matter what they do; g'back both of you and bind Melanthius' hands
and feet behind him. Throw him int'the store room and make the door
fast behind you; then fasten a noose about his body, and string him
close up t'the rafters from a high bearing-post,172 that he may linger
on in an agony."
Thus did he speak, and they did even as he had said; they went t'the
store room, which they entered before Melanthius saw them, for he was
busy searching for arms in the innermost part of the room, s'the two
took their stand on either side of the door and waited. By and by
Melanthius came out with a helmet in one hand, and an old dry-rotted
shield in the other, which had been borne by Laertes when he was young,
but which had been long since thrown aside, and the straps had become
unsewn; on this the tw'seized him, dragged him back by the hair, and
threw him struggling t'the ground. They bent his hands and feet well
behind his back, and bound them tight with a painful bond as Ulysses
had told them; then they fastened a noose about his body and strung him
up from a high pillar till he was close up t'the rafters, and over him
did you then vaunt, 'swineherd Eumaeus saying, "Melanthius, you will
pass the night on a soft bed as you deserve. You will know very well
when morning comes from the streams of Oceanus, and it is time for you
t'be driving in your goats for the suitors t'feast on."

characters.importance_exp: Revenge is central to Ulysses' actions in this scene.
characters.quote: Ulysses answered, "Telemachus and I will hold these suitors in check, n'matter what they do; g'back both of you and bind Melanthius' hands and feet behind him."

scenes.title: Minerva's Support
scenes.summary: Minerva aids Ulysses in battle.
scenes.explanation: Minerva's arrival changes the dynamics of the fight.
scenes.text:
There, then, they left him in very cruel bondage, and having put on
their armour they closed the door behind them and went back t'take
their places by the side of Ulysses; whereon the four men stood in the
cloister, fierce and full of fury; nevertheless, those wh'were in the
body of the court were still both brave and many. Then Jove's daughter
Minerva came up t'them, having assumed the voice and form of Mentor.
Ulysses was glad when he saw her and said, "Mentor, lend me your help,
and forget not your old comrade, nor the many good turns he has done
you. Besides, you are my age-mate."
But all the time he felt sure it was Minerva, and the suitors from the
other side raised an uproar when they saw her. Agelaus was the first to
reproach her. "Mentor," he cried, "d'not let Ulysses beguile you into
siding with him and fighting the suitors. This is what we will do: when
we have killed these people, father and son, we will kill you too. You
shall pay for it with your head, and when we have killed you, we will
take all you have, in doors or out, and bring it int'hotch-pot with
Ulysses' property; we will not let your sons live in your house, nor
your daughters, nor shall your widow continue t'live in the city of
Ithaca."
This made Minerva still more furious, s'she scolded Ulysses very
angrily.173 "Ulysses," said she, "your strength and prowess are no
longer what they were when you fought for nine long years among the
Trojans about the noble lady Helen. You killed many a man in those
days, and it was through your stratagem that Priam's city was taken.
How comes it that you are s'lamentably less valiant now that you are
on your own ground, face t'face with the suitors in your own house?
Come on, my good fellow, stand by my side and see how Mentor, son of
Alcimus shall fight your foes and requite your kindnesses conferred
upon him."
But she would not give him full victory as yet, for she wished still
further t'prove his own prowess and that of his brave son, s'she flew
up t'one of the rafters in the roof of the cloister and sat upon it in
the form of a swallow.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Minerva's presence is crucial for Ulysses' success.
characters.quote: Ulysses was glad when he saw her and said, "Mentor, lend me your help, and forget not your old comrade, nor the many good turns he has done you."

characters.name: Independence
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' bravery is questioned, highlighting his struggle.
characters.quote: How comes it that you are s'lamentably less valiant now that you are on your own ground, face t'face with the suitors in your own house?

characters.name: Threat And Conflict
characters.importance_exp: The suitors' threats escalate the tension in the scene.
characters.quote: we will kill you too. You shall pay for it with your head, and when we have killed you, we will take all you have, in doors or out, and bring it int'hotch-pot with Ulysses' property;

scenes.title: The Battle Intensifies
scenes.summary: The suitors fight back against Ulysses and his men.
scenes.explanation: The battle escalates with more action.
scenes.text:
Meanwhile Agelaus son of Damastor, Eurynomus, Amphimedon, Demoptolemus,
Pisander, and Polybus son of Polyctor bore the brunt of the fight upon
the suitors' side; of all those wh'were still fighting for their lives
they were by far the most valiant, for the others had already fallen
under the arrows of Ulysses. Agelaus shouted t'them and said, "My
friends, he will soon have t'leave off, for Mentor has gone away after
having done nothing for him but brag. They are standing at the doors
unsupported. D'not aim at him all at once, but six of you throw your
spears first, and see if you cannot cover yourselves with glory by
killing him. When he has fallen we need not be uneasy about the
others."
They threw their spears as he bade them, but Minerva made them all of
n'effect. One hit the door post; another went against the door; the
pointed shaft of another struck the wall; and as soon as they had
avoided all the spears of the suitors Ulysses said t'his own men, "My
friends, I should say we to'had better let drive int'the middle of
them, or they will crown all the harm they have done us by killing us
outright."
They therefore aimed straight in front of them and threw their spears.
Ulysses killed Demoptolemus, Telemachus Euryades, Eumaeus Elatus, while
the stockman killed Pisander. These all bit the dust, and as the others
drew back int'a corner Ulysses and his men rushed forward and regained
their spears by drawing them from the bodies of the dead.
The suitors now aimed a second time, but again Minerva made their
weapons for the most part without effect. One hit a bearing-post of the
cloister; another went against the door; while the pointed shaft of
another struck the wall. Still, Amphimedon just took a piece of the top
skin from off Telemachus's wrist, and Ctesippus managed t'graze
Eumaeus's shoulder above his shield; but the spear went on and fell to
the ground. Then Ulysses and his men let drive int'the crowd of
suitors. Ulysses hit Eurydamas, Telemachus Amphimedon, and Eumaeus
Polybus. After this the stockman hit Ctesippus in the breast, and
taunted him saying, "Foul-mouthed son of Polytherses, d'not be so
foolish as t'talk wickedly another time, but let heaven direct your
speech, for the gods are far stronger than men. I make you a present of
this advice t'repay you for the foot which you gave Ulysses when he
was begging about in his own house."
Thus spoke the stockman, and Ulysses struck the son of Damastor with a
spear in close fight, while Telemachus hit Leocritus son of Evenor in
the belly, and the dart went clean through him, s'that he fell forward
full on his face upon the ground. Then Minerva from her seat on the
rafter held up her deadly aegis, and the hearts of the suitors quailed.
They fled t'the other end of the court like a herd of cattle maddened
by the gadfly in early summer when the days are at their longest. As
eagle-beaked, crook-taloned vultures from the mountains swoop down on
the smaller birds that cower in flocks upon the ground, and kill them,
for they cannot either fight or fly, and lookers on enjoy the
sport—even s'did Ulysses and his men fall upon the suitors and smite
them on every side. They made a horrible groaning as their brains were
being battered in, and the ground seethed with their blood.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Minerva's influence is crucial in the battle.
characters.quote: But Minerva made them all of n'effect.

characters.name: Retribution
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses seeks vengeance against the suitors.
characters.quote: Thus spoke the stockman, and Ulysses struck the son of Damastor with a spear in close fight.

characters.name: Desperation For Help
characters.importance_exp: The suitors are terrified and desperate as they flee.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The panic felt by Ulysses and his men underscores the urgency and dread of impending conflict.

scenes.title: The Pleas for Mercy
scenes.summary: Leiodes and Phemius plead for their lives.
scenes.explanation: The location shifts as Ulysses confronts the remaining suitors.
scenes.text:
Leiodes then caught the knees of Ulysses and said, "Ulysses I beseech
you have mercy upon me and spare me. I never wronged any of the women
in your house either in word or deed, and I tried t'stop the others. I
saw them, but they would not listen, and now they are paying for their
folly. I was their sacrificing priest; if you kill me, I shall die
without having done anything t'deserve it, and shall have got no
thanks for all the good that I did."
Ulysses looked sternly at him and answered, "If you were their
sacrificing priest, you must have prayed many a time that it might be
long before I got home again, and that you might marry my wife and have
children by her. Therefore you shall die."
With these words he picked up the sword that Agelaus had dropped when
he was being killed, and which was lying upon the ground. Then he
struck Leiodes on the back of his neck, s'that his head fell rolling
in the dust while he was yet speaking.
The minstrel Phemius son of Terpes—he wh'had been forced by the
suitors t'sing t'them—now tried t'save his life. He was standing
near towards the trap door,174 and held his lyre in his hand. He did
not know whether t'fly out of the cloister and sit down by the altar
of Jove that was in the outer court, and on which both Laertes and
Ulysses had offered up the thigh bones of many an ox, or whether t'go
straight up t'Ulysses and embrace his knees, but in the end he deemed
it best t'embrace Ulysses' knees. S'he laid his lyre on the ground
between the mixing bowl 175 and the silver-studded seat; then going up
t'Ulysses he caught hold of his knees and said, "Ulysses, I beseech
you have mercy on me and spare me. You will be sorry for it afterwards
if you kill a bard wh'can sing both for gods and men as I can. I make
all my lays myself, and heaven visits me with every kind of
inspiration. I would sing t'you as though you were a god, d'not
therefore be in such a hurry t'cut my head off. Your own son
Telemachus will tell you that I did not want t'frequent your house and
sing t'the suitors after their meals, but they were to'many and too
strong for me, s'they made me."
Telemachus heard him, and at once went up t'his father. "Hold!" he
cried, "the man is guiltless, d'him n'hurt; and we will spare Medon
too, wh'was always good t'me when I was a boy, unless Philoetius or
Eumaeus has already killed him, or he has fallen in your way when you
were raging about the court."
Medon caught these words of Telemachus, for he was crouching under a
seat beneath which he had hidden by covering himself up with a freshly
flayed heifer's hide, s'he threw off the hide, went up t'Telemachus,
and laid hold of his knees.
"Here I am, my dear sir," said he, "stay your hand therefore, and tell
your father, or he will kill me in his rage against the suitors for
having wasted his substance and been s'foolishly disrespectful to
yourself."
Ulysses smiled at him and answered, "Fear not; Telemachus has saved
your life, that you may know in future, and tell other people, how
greatly better good deeds prosper than evil ones. Go, therefore,
outside the cloisters int'the outer court, and be out of the way of

characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the conflict between Ulysses and the suitors.
characters.quote: Ulysses, I beseech you have mercy upon me and spare me.

characters.importance_exp: The characters are desperately trying to save their lives amidst chaos.
characters.quote: Ulysses, I beseech you have mercy on me and spare me.

characters.importance_exp: The consequences of past actions are highlighted in Ulysses' decisions.

scenes.title: The Aftermath of the Battle
scenes.summary: Ulysses orders the cleanup and punishment of the disloyal maids.
scenes.explanation: The scene changes to the aftermath of the battle.
scenes.text:
the slaughter—you and the bard—while I finish my work here inside."
The pair went int'the outer court as fast as they could, and sat down
by Jove's great altar, looking fearfully round, and still expecting
that they would be killed. Then Ulysses searched the whole court
carefully over, t'see if anyone had managed t'hide himself and was
still living, but he found them all lying in the dust and weltering in
their blood. They were like fishes which fishermen have netted out of
the sea, and thrown upon the beach t'lie gasping for water till the
heat of the sun makes an end of them. Even s'were the suitors lying
all huddled up one against the other.
Then Ulysses said t'Telemachus, "Call nurse Euryclea; I have something
t'say t'her."
Telemachus went and knocked at the door of the women's room. "Make
haste," said he, "you old woman wh'have been set over all the other
women in the house. Come outside; my father wishes t'speak t'you."
When Euryclea heard this she unfastened the door of the women's room
and came out, following Telemachus. She found Ulysses among the corpses
bespattered with blood and filth like a lion that has just been
devouring an ox, and his breast and both his cheeks are all bloody, so
that he is a fearful sight; even s'was Ulysses besmirched from head to
foot with gore. When she saw all the corpses and such a quantity of
blood, she was beginning t'cry out for joy, for she saw that a great
deed had been done; but Ulysses checked her, "Old woman," said he,
"rejoice in silence; restrain yourself, and d'not make any noise about
it; it is an unholy thing t'vaunt over dead men. Heaven's doom and
their own evil deeds have brought these men t'destruction, for they
respected n'man in the whole world, neither rich nor poor, wh'came
near them, and they have come t'a bad end as a punishment for their
wickedness and folly. Now, however, tell me which of the women in the
house have misconducted themselves, and wh'are innocent."176
"I will tell you the truth, my son," answered Euryclea. "There are
fifty women in the house whom we teach t'd'things, such as carding
wool, and all kinds of household work. Of these, twelve in all177 have
misbehaved, and have been wanting in respect t'me, and als'to
Penelope. They showed n'disrespect t'Telemachus, for he has only
lately grown and his mother never permitted him t'give orders t'the
female servants; but let me g'upstairs and tell your wife all that has
happened, for some god has been sending her t'sleep."
"D'not wake her yet," answered Ulysses, "but tell the women wh'have
misconducted themselves t'come t'me."
Euryclea left the cloister t'tell the women, and make them come to
Ulysses; in the meantime he called Telemachus, the stockman, and the
swineherd. "Begin," said he, "t'remove the dead, and make the women
help you. Then, get sponges and clean water t'swill down the tables
and seats. When you have thoroughly cleansed the whole cloisters, take
the women int'the space between the domed room and the wall of the
outer court, and run them through with your swords till they are quite
dead, and have forgotten all about love and the way in which they used
t'lie in secret with the suitors."
On this the women came down in a body, weeping and wailing bitterly.
First they carried the dead bodies out, and propped them up against one
another in the gatehouse. Ulysses ordered them about and made them do
their work quickly, s'they had t'carry the bodies out. When they had
done this, they cleaned all the tables and seats with sponges and
water, while Telemachus and the tw'others shovelled up the blood and
dirt from the ground, and the women carried it all away and put it out
of doors. Then when they had made the whole place quite clean and
orderly, they took the women out and hemmed them in the narrow space
between the wall of the domed room and that of the yard, s'that they
could not get away: and Telemachus said t'the other two, "I shall not
let these women die a clean death, for they were insolent t'me and my
mother, and used t'sleep with the suitors."
S'saying he made a ship's cable fast t'one of the bearing-posts that
supported the roof of the domed room, and secured it all around the
building, at a good height, lest any of the women's feet should touch
the ground; and as thrushes or doves beat against a net that has been
set for them in a thicket just as they were getting t'their nest, and
a terrible fate awaits them, even s'did the women have t'put their
heads in nooses one after the other and die most miserably.178 Their
feet moved convulsively for a while, but not for very long.
As for Melanthius, they took him through the cloister int'the inner
court. There they cut off his nose and his ears; they drew out his
vitals and gave them t'the dogs raw, and then in their fury they cut
off his hands and his feet.
When they had done this they washed their hands and feet and went back
int'the house, for all was now over; and Ulysses said t'the dear old
nurse Euryclea, "Bring me sulphur, which cleanses all pollution, and
fetch fire als'that I may burn it, and purify the cloisters. Go,
moreover, and tell Penelope t'come here with her attendants, and also
all the maidservants that are in the house."

scenes.title: The Reunion with Euryclea
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks with Euryclea about the events.
scenes.explanation: The chapter concludes with a reunion.
scenes.text:
"All that you have said is true," answered Euryclea, "but let me bring
you some clean clothes—a shirt and cloak. D'not keep these rags on
your back any longer. It is not right."
"First light me a fire," replied Ulysses.
She brought the fire and sulphur, as he had bidden her, and Ulysses
thoroughly purified the cloisters and both the inner and outer courts.
Then she went inside t'call the women and tell them what had happened;
whereon they came from their apartment with torches in their hands, and
pressed round Ulysses t'embrace him, kissing his head and shoulders
and taking hold of his hands. It made him feel as if he should like to
weep, for he remembered every one of them.179

characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the scene as it marks Ulysses' return.
characters.quote: It made him feel as if he should like to weep, for he remembered every one of them.

characters.importance_exp: The reunion with the women highlights emotional connections.

scenes.title: Recognition of Ulysses
scenes.summary: Penelope learns of Ulysses' return.
scenes.explanation: Start of chapter.
scenes.text:
PENELOPE EVENTUALLY RECOGNISES HER HUSBAND—EARLY IN THE MORNING
ULYSSES, TELEMACHUS, EUMAEUS, AND PHILOETIUS LEAVE THE TOWN.
Euryclea now went upstairs laughing t'tell her mistress that her dear
husband had come home. Her aged knees became young again and her feet
were nimble for joy as she went up t'her mistress and bent over her
head t'speak t'her. "Wake up Penelope, my dear child," she exclaimed,
"and see with your own eyes something that you have been wanting this
long time past. Ulysses has at last indeed come home again, and has
killed the suitors wh'were giving s'much trouble in his house, eating
up his estate and ill treating his son."
"My good nurse," answered Penelope, "you must be mad. The gods
sometimes send some very sensible people out of their minds, and make
foolish people become sensible. This is what they must have been doing
t'you; for you always used t'be a reasonable person. Why should you
thus mock me when I have trouble enough already—talking such nonsense,
and waking me up out of a sweet sleep that had taken possession of my
eyes and closed them? I have never slept s'soundly from the day my
poor husband went t'that city with the ill-omened name. G'back again
int'the women's room; if it had been any one else wh'had woke me up
t'bring me such absurd news I should have sent her away with a severe
scolding. As it is your age shall protect you."
"My dear child," answered Euryclea, "I am not mocking you. It is quite
true as I tell you that Ulysses is come home again. He was the stranger
whom they all kept on treating s'badly in the cloister. Telemachus
knew all the time that he was come back, but kept his father's secret
that he might have his revenge on all these wicked people."
Then Penelope sprang up from her couch, threw her arms round Euryclea,
and wept for joy. "But my dear nurse," said she, "explain this t'me;
if he has really come home as you say, how did he manage t'overcome
the wicked suitors single handed, seeing what a number of them there
always were?"
"I was not there," answered Euryclea, "and d'not know; I only heard
them groaning while they were being killed. We sat crouching and
huddled up in a corner of the women's room with the doors closed, till
your son came t'fetch me because his father sent him. Then I found
Ulysses standing over the corpses that were lying on the ground all
round him, one on top of the other. You would have enjoyed it if you
could have seen him standing there all bespattered with blood and
filth, and looking just like a lion. But the corpses are now all piled
up in the gatehouse that is in the outer court, and Ulysses has lit a
great fire t'purify the house with sulphur. He has sent me t'call
you, s'come with me that you may both be happy together after all; for
now at last the desire of your heart has been fulfilled; your husband
is come home t'find both wife and son alive and well, and t'take his
revenge in his own house on the suitors wh'behaved s'badly t'him."

characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the scene as it marks Ulysses' return.
characters.quote: Ulysses has at last indeed come home again, and has killed the suitors wh'were giving s'much trouble in his house, eating up his estate and ill treating his son.

characters.importance_exp: Penelope's recognition of Ulysses is a pivotal moment.
characters.quote: Then Penelope sprang up from her couch, threw her arms round Euryclea, and wept for joy.

characters.name: Hope For Return
characters.importance_exp: Penelope's hope for Ulysses' return drives her emotions.
characters.quote: if he has really come home as you say, how did he manage t'overcome the wicked suitors single handed, seeing what a number of them there always were?

scenes.title: Penelope's Doubts 2
scenes.summary: Penelope expresses disbelief about Ulysses' return.
scenes.explanation: Penelope questions the news.
scenes.text:
"My dear nurse," said Penelope, "d'not exult to'confidently over all
this. You know how delighted every one would be t'see Ulysses come
home—more particularly myself, and the son wh'has been born t'both of
us; but what you tell me cannot be really true. It is some god wh'is
angry with the suitors for their great wickedness, and has made an end
of them; for they respected n'man in the whole world, neither rich nor
poor, wh'came near them, and they have come t'a bad end in
consequence of their iniquity; Ulysses is dead far away from the
Achaean land; he will never return home again."
Then nurse Euryclea said, "My child, what are you talking about? but
you were all hard of belief and have made up your mind that your
husband is never coming, although he is in the house and by his own
fire side at this very moment. Besides I can give you another proof;
when I was washing him I perceived the scar which the wild boar gave
him, and I wanted t'tell you about it, but in his wisdom he would not
let me, and clapped his hands over my mouth; s'come with me and I will
make this bargain with you—if I am deceiving you, you may have me
killed by the most cruel death you can think of."
"My dear nurse," said Penelope, "however wise you may be you can hardly
fathom the counsels of the gods. Nevertheless, we will g'in search of
my son, that I may see the corpses of the suitors, and the man wh'has

scenes.title: Ulysses and Penelope Meet
scenes.summary: Penelope and Ulysses finally meet face to face.
scenes.explanation: Penelope approaches Ulysses.
scenes.text:
him. When, however, she had crossed the stone floor of the cloister,
she sat down opposite Ulysses by the fire, against the wall at right
angles180 [t'that by which she had entered], while Ulysses sat near
one of the bearing-posts, looking upon the ground, and waiting t'see
what his brave wife would say t'him when she saw him. For a long time
she sat silent and as one lost in amazement. At one moment she looked
him full in the face, but then again directly, she was misled by his
shabby clothes and failed t'recognise him,181 till Telemachus began to
reproach her and said:
"Mother—but you are s'hard that I cannot call you by such a name—why
d'you keep away from my father in this way? Why d'you not sit by his
side and begin talking t'him and asking him questions? N'other woman
could bear t'keep away from her husband when he had come back t'her
after twenty years of absence, and after having gone through s'much;
but your heart always was as hard as a stone."
Penelope answered, "My son, I am s'lost in astonishment that I can
find n'words in which either t'ask questions or t'answer them. I
cannot even look him straight in the face. Still, if he really is
Ulysses come back t'his own home again, we shall get t'understand one
another better by and by, for there are tokens with which we tw'are
alone acquainted, and which are hidden from all others."
Ulysses smiled at this, and said t'Telemachus, "Let your mother put me
t'any proof she likes; she will make up her mind about it presently.
She rejects me for the moment and believes me t'be somebody else,
because I am covered with dirt and have such bad clothes on; let us,

scenes.title: The Test of the Bed
scenes.summary: Penelope tests Ulysses with the bed story.
scenes.explanation: Penelope questions Ulysses about their bed.
scenes.text:
gone through s'much. But come, nurse, get a bed ready for me; I will
sleep alone, for this woman has a heart as hard as iron."
"My dear," answered Penelope, "I have n'wish t'set myself up, nor to
depreciate you; but I am not struck by your appearance, for I very well
remember what kind of a man you were when you set sail from Ithaca.
Nevertheless, Euryclea, take his bed outside the bed chamber that he
himself built. Bring the bed outside this room, and put bedding upon it
with fleeces, good coverlets, and blankets."
She said this t'try him, but Ulysses was very angry and said, "Wife, I
am much displeased at what you have just been saying. Wh'has been
taking my bed from the place in which I left it? He must have found it
a hard task, n'matter how skilled a workman he was, unless some god
came and helped him t'shift it. There is n'man living, however strong
and in his prime, wh'could move it from its place, for it is a
marvellous curiosity which I made with my very own hands. There was a
young olive growing within the precincts of the house, in full vigour,
and about as thick as a bearing-post. I built my room round this with
strong walls of stone and a roof t'cover them, and I made the doors
strong and well-fitting. Then I cut off the top boughs of the olive
tree and left the stump standing. This I dressed roughly from the root
upwards and then worked with carpenter's tools well and skilfully,
straightening my work by drawing a line on the wood, and making it into
a bed-prop. I then bored a hole down the middle, and made it the
centre-post of my bed, at which I worked till I had finished it,
inlaying it with gold and silver; after this I stretched a hide of
crimson leather from one side of it t'the other. S'you see I know all
about it, and I desire t'learn whether it is still there, or whether
any one has been removing it by cutting down the olive tree at its
roots."

characters.quote: I will sleep alone, for this woman has a heart as hard as iron.

characters.quote: Wife, I am much displeased at what you have just been saying.

scenes.title: Reunion and Love
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Penelope embrace after the test.
scenes.explanation: Penelope accepts Ulysses after the test.
scenes.text:
When she heard the sure proofs Ulysses now gave her, she fairly broke
down. She flew weeping t'his side, flung her arms about his neck, and
kissed him. "D'not be angry with me Ulysses," she cried, "you, wh'are
the wisest of mankind. We have suffered, both of us. Heaven has denied
us the happiness of spending our youth, and of growing old, together;
d'not then be aggrieved or take it amiss that I did not embrace you
thus as soon as I saw you. I have been shuddering all the time through
fear that someone might come here and deceive me with a lying story;
for there are many very wicked people going about. Jove's daughter
Helen would never have yielded herself t'a man from a foreign country,
if she had known that the sons of Achaeans would come after her and
bring her back. Heaven put it in her heart t'd'wrong, and she gave no
thought t'that sin, which has been the source of all our sorrows. Now,
however, that you have convinced me by showing that you know all about
our bed (which n'human being has ever seen but you and I and a single
maidservant, the daughter of Actor, wh'was given me by my father on my
marriage, and wh'keeps the doors of our room) hard of belief though I
have been I can mistrust n'longer."
Then Ulysses in his turn melted, and wept as he clasped his dear and
faithful wife t'his bosom. As the sight of land is welcome t'men who
are swimming towards the shore, when Neptune has wrecked their ship
with the fury of his winds and waves; a few alone reach the land, and
these, covered with brine, are thankful when they find themselves on
firm ground and out of danger—even s'was her husband welcome t'her as
she looked upon him, and she could not tear her tw'fair arms from
about his neck. Indeed they would have gone on indulging their sorrow
till rosy-fingered morn appeared, had not Minerva determined otherwise,

characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the emotional climax of the scene.
characters.quote: She flew weeping t'his side, flung her arms about his neck, and kissed him.

characters.name: Disguise And Deception
characters.importance_exp: Trust issues are pivotal in Penelope's initial hesitation.
characters.quote: I have been shuddering all the time through fear that someone might come here and deceive me with a lying story;

characters.name: Enduring Suffering
characters.importance_exp: The theme reflects the pain both characters have endured.

scenes.title: Plans for the Future
scenes.summary: Ulysses discusses future plans with Penelope.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses speaks of future challenges.
scenes.text:
At last, however, Ulysses said, "Wife, we have not yet reached the end
of our troubles. I have an unknown amount of toil still t'undergo. It
is long and difficult, but I must g'through with it, for thus the
shade of Teiresias prophesied concerning me, on the day when I went
down int'Hades t'ask about my return and that of my companions. But
now let us g't'bed, that we may lie down and enjoy the blessed boon
of sleep."
"You shall g't'bed as soon as you please," replied Penelope, "now
that the gods have sent you home t'your own good house and t'your
country. But as heaven has put it in your mind t'speak of it, tell me
about the task that lies before you. I shall have t'hear about it
later, s'it is better that I should be told at once."
"My dear," answered Ulysses, "why should you press me t'tell you?
Still, I will not conceal it from you, though you will not like it. I
d'not like it myself, for Teiresias bade me travel far and wide,
carrying an oar, till I came t'a country where the people have never
heard of the sea, and d'not even mix salt with their food. They know
nothing about ships, nor oars that are as the wings of a ship. He gave
me this certain token which I will not hide from you. He said that a
wayfarer should meet me and ask me whether it was a winnowing shovel
that I had on my shoulder. On this, I was t'fix my oar in the ground
and sacrifice a ram, a bull, and a boar t'Neptune; after which I was
t'g'home and offer hecatombs t'all the gods in heaven, one after the
other. As for myself, he said that death should come t'me from the
sea, and that my life should ebb away very gently when I was full of
years and peace of mind, and my people should bless me. All this, he
said, should surely come t'pass."
And Penelope said, "If the gods are going t'vouchsafe you a happier
time in your old age, you may hope then t'have some respite from
misfortune."

characters.importance_exp: Ulysses must continue to endure hardships despite returning home.
characters.quote: I have an unknown amount of toil still t'undergo.

characters.quote: Teiresias bade me travel far and wide, carrying an oar, till I came t'a country where the people have never heard of the sea.
